description:
*** IMPORTANT NOTE: THE VERSION LINKED TO CURRENTLY IS NOT THE LD VERSION. I ACCIDENTALLY OVERWROTE THE LD VERSION AND DON'T HAVE A BACKUP. PLAY IF YOU WANT, AND LEAVE COMMENTS, BUT PLEASE DO NOT VOTE, AS IT WILL BE UNFAIR TO OTHERS ***
This is a real-time space trading game with a dynamic economy. I didn't pack all the features in that I wanted, but I think it's still pretty cool, and I'll definitely polish it up over the next week!
Basic instructions here: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/04/25/basic-instructions-for-sky-traders-of-jupiter/
NOTE: Due to time constraints, I didn't have a chance to test the gameplay much, and as a result, the Ludum Dare version is much too hard! Very hard to make a profit, and, as has been pointed out in the comments, getting robbed is essentially game over. Better balance is definitely priority #1 for the post-Ludum version... I hope you won't be TOO harsh in the voting out of frustration.
NOTE 2: I didn't know that submitting source was obligatory. I'm submitting now, but didn't keep a copy of the non-LD version. About two hours of work has gone into this since the end of LD, so don't accuse me of cheating if you decide to compile the source and discover it's significantly less buggy and more fun than the compiled LD version.
author: Xopods
title: Sky Traders of Jupiter
comments: Sweet game. I managed to get bankrupt a few times but sweet :D
Lovely game. It's tough getting the profit ball rolling. Seems that getting robbed once is game over.

There's actually some kind of bug where selling a whole bunch in a row sends your cash suddenly into the negative.

But other than that, really impressive simulation game. Liked it a lot!

Nice. Has a good board-game feel to it. It would have been nice to either stop time when you are stationary, or be able to roll over the material on the right to see prices at each city, so I'm not spending so much time deciding which trade route to take. The gameplay was very well thought out for a 48h game, I like it.

It's not exactly my type of game, therefore I refrain from voting on Overall and Fun.
From what I can see it's a very polished entry, but i fail to get anywhere. I've travelled (and walked) back and forth a bit, but wasn't really able to get at higher credits; it did go up a bit though ;)
Great concept! Nice artwork, too. Not my type of game, but I totally respect what you were able to accomplish here.

title: X by Allefant

navigation is ... weeeeiird.  I floated around a little on my boat, picked some people up, and dropped some people off.  A happy day : )

that was very hard to control, I didn't really get what was going on.. :-(

description:
Puzzle/adventure, 2D-platformer.
Engine: Flixel (FlashDevelop)
Music: Musagi
SFX: sfxr
Pixels: Graphics Gale and Inkscape
Map: Mappy
I feel that this LD has been much more productive for me. The scope of this game is larger, much larger, than the last one. The mechanism is intriguing to me, and I wish I had more time to explore it further. This project might have a continuation as well.
The initial idea was to use the "island" theme as a metaphor, which brought forth the cloning mechanic.
Photo from ending screen taken by myself during the competition.
You can see it here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/coldphage/4551600499/
(I hope my server holds up!)
author: eli
title: You are me now
comments: Interesting. I got almost stuck in one area and had to R my way out of there. The mind harp is the ending?
Great use of the theme, clever game mechanics and level!
Nice gameplay mechanics! I think you could've done the same with much smaller game area, though...
Very clever. I enjoyed it quite a bit :)
This is a great game: Nice concept, I especially like C key mechanic.

I really enjoyed this.  :)  The split-personality (or whatever you might call it) mechanic was neat and the gameplay was paced well. I do wish the character handled a little better though (jumping was tricky at points.)

This is really cool. I like the quote at the start.
The platforming was a bit clunky because the horizontal acceleration of the player is so small one has to back up and get a running start for even the simplest of jumps.
The mind switching mechanics were very neat, although it wasn't immediately obvious that it was the pink squares on which my ghost was able to walk.
Also, the whole world felt like a single island, and lowering the water level felt like seeing more of the one island, not allowing access to another island. This is a small complaint, but the game seemed to imply that I wanted to get to other islands, not just more of this one.

Fun game. I really liked the idea of connecting islands through lowering water. With literary reference too, and extending the metaphor to connecting you with your enemies through mind powers. :-)
The player character was kinda slow. I think the game would feel better if he was faster.
I liked it. It was a tad slow-paced but it was very creative.
I think everything about this was spot on. I loved it :)
I like the idea, good game. I have cheated some how, I controlled an enemy who was near the end of the game, and then I win.
neat idea, I like it. good work

The idea is great, but the player movement is terrible. He accelerates far too slowly: really kills the fun.

A more fleshed-out version with that fixed would have a lot of potential.

Great music, great idea, but the character movement made it not as fun as it could've been, still a very well put together effort for the time and I absolutely loved all the little touches like the shaking when you die. Mucho impressivo!
I LOVED the music in this. Ambient, atmospheric, almost entrancing. The game was nifty as well, even though the mechanics were a bit rough. The overall idea was brilliant. Good work!
The mechanics were awesome. A bit slow for all the backtracking though.

A nice, innovative, complete experience :)  Superb music.

The sluggish horizontal movement was a bit of a pain, mostly because it'd have been easily to fix.  The back tracking would have been frustrating had the game been longer, but it rounded off at an appropriate time.

Not really sure I understand the philosophical allusions, felt a bit unfocused to be truly meaningful.  I'm just nitpicking though, it was great.

description:
UPDATE: Thanks for the feedback on the crashes guys - seems it was a buggy opengl32.dll that a botched install of VStudio stuck on my machine. (Don't even use VStudio). Anyways, should all be fine now and I've uploaded a Linux port now too :) - it requires libglut - so please "sudo apt-get install libglut3" or however you manage your packages
-----
Premise:
---
You are a lone alien scout ship, sent to find a new colony for your alien friends... or
something... Anyways, the planet is full of water, you and your alien buddies hate the
stuff. Lucky for you there are loads of flying island parts. Use your space ship to drag
these parts down to the middle of the ocean and build on the existing island so its big
enough for all the freaky alien types who might follow.
-----
Controls:
---
Arrows - move ship
Spacebar - activate grapple
P - pauses
----
Known issues:
---
- some of the islands get randomly stuck in the air
- some vsync issues causing tearing on some machines
- HUD is jittery as all hell, due to a rounding error I was not keen on chasing down
- The "story" text seems to only work when it wants too.
- Also the "story" text scrolls uber fast on the linux build. Not a"show-stopper" so now fixies. :(
-----
Ah well its my first LUDUM DARE! AND I SUBMITTED! :)
GRIEVE
author: TheGrieve

comments:
---------------------------

OK

"The procedure entry point _ftol2 could not be located in the dynamic link library msvcrt.dll"

Aiming and flinging things down range was quite enjoyable, though with no position/velocity reference in the background, the radar was more useful, but it didn't show my island's shape.

Got 2484.57

The game crashed. Am I missing a library? I got the same message zorbathut got.

Nice concept. It plays smooth and was intuitive. It's only hard at the beginning, though. I found it easy to outpace the rising water. One strategy that works pretty well is to just fly around flinging the spazzing balls randomly (or better, towards the island), since they glom on their own.

The intro text scrolls way too fast on windows, too.
I swore that the vibrating hud was an earthquake, and all of a sudden I feared for my tall and thin tower. :)
I observed one spaz ball that I could attach my grapple to, but that would not be pulled. It'd just stretch my grapple all the way across the level.

Hi-score 2048

"The procedure entry point _ftol2 could not be located in the dynamic link library msvcrt.dll"

How'd you manage that? That function is part of the C runtime.

To everyone who didn't get it to work, I got the same error as you and made it work just by renaming the .dll's included. Deleting them would have also worked. This is not guaranteed to work though. (I'm using Windows XP, which might also be your problem. As noted in TheGrieve's blog posts.)

Planetfall was fun, and I played it until the screen was almost clear. Finally died in the water, because my last planet chunks were down there and I couldn't find a way to regain health. There was also a bug where a few chunks wouldn't move, but that's just a bug.

The game was neat, and I really enjoyed playing it. :)

Congratulations on your first LD! I thought this was pretty fun.

On my best attempt, I started by throwing islands around randomly because aiming was too much effort - that got me to a safe height, then I had time to aim precisely but the game was too easy from that point.

I like the fuzzy outlines and how they translate into solid shapes.

I couldn't play. Same error:

"The procedure point _ftol2 could not be located in the dynamic link library msvcrt.dll"

I'm using XP. I will try on a Vista PC later.

Gameplay needs some tuning, but very solid idea, and it was quite exciting. I kept burying myself deep in the ocean, but it's hard to tell if reducing glide would make it more fun.

I liked the multiple-grapple mechanism, and the balance between time and the blue grapple meter.

Congrats on your first entry!! Good work.
Managed to get it to run by deleting all of the dlls except freeglut.dll! Unfortunately it flickers pretty hard on my machine... :(
Man, those instructions FLY by. The game works well. Nice ideas!

description:
This is a quite simple game about Pirates, a treasure, Robinson Crusoe
and an island.
Timelapse here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cMf1bfnPV-E
The goal is very simple: Robinson Crusoe, alone on his island
has to protect his treasure form an army of pirates.
It is written in java, with lwjgl library. Graphic are made
with Inkscape and Gimp.
REQUIRED:
- Windows XP or later, Linux, may work on MacOS but not tested
- Java Runtime Environment 1.6 (may work with 1.5 but not tester)
- Opengl support (hardware or software)
CONTROLS:
- use arrows to move
- Space for hit
- Right control for BIG hit! (can be re-done only 10 seconds after using it)
- Echap for quit
- After game over you can quit by pressing "Echap" or restart by pressing "Space"
SCORE:
It is printed at the top of the screen. There is more and more
pirates and score grow faster and faster.
LAUNCH:
- On Linux: go to the directory with a shell and type "./pirates.sh"
- On windows: go to the directory whith a shell and type "pirates.bat"
- On MacOS: I don't know the exact command. If you are familiar with java
see the script content, and put native/macosx in the Java.library.path
Enjoy!
author: kplbe
title: Pirates
comments: Hilarious art. For gameplay, I think it might help to have something drawing the player elsewhere, or else the optimal strategy becomes to just sit on the chest and attack.
Brilliant sprites.  Gameplay balance seemed pretty good until you realise you can just sit on the treasure.
Like others said, you can just sit on the chest and win. And smooth controls wouldn't have been that hard to do, either. Nice sprites though.
The sprites are cute, I like them. Especially the way they fall apart when you hit them.

Nice art.
Nitpicks are the control with the keyboard delay and a bit more diversity with the enemies.
Other than that nice game.

description:
You are the pilot of a bomber plane carrying out a nuclear test. Navigate to the island marked on the radar. The monotonous scenery and lack of sensory stimulation may cause disorienting hallucinations.
Use LEFT and RIGHT to steer.
UPDATE: Hopefully fixed crash, speed, graphical glitches. Try Bugfix version if you have any problems.
author: sf17k
title: Nuclear Test
comments: Got to say, this is amazing. There's not really much I can add other than this one got me. Kudos for doing something interesting with "islands", too. I appreciate you post on themes, as well.

OH GOD THE CHEESES ARE COMING AGAIN BUT NO WAIT THEY'RE DICE AAAAAH
amazing work man, thanks for the trip.
I'm sad that this crashes on windows. I was looking forward to the disorienting hallucinations.

Got a lot out of this  The dull roar of the engines, blink inducing hallucinations, and the ending were all pitch perfect.  I also particularly liked the way the gameplay encouraged a sort of phased out hyper-awareness that's familiar from long stints of motorway driving, seemed very apt.

Didn't appreciate the parting theme stab though, felt needlessly bitter (critism deserved or not), and tarnished the preceeding endgame.
Great game, surprisingly polished and complete.
You were complaining in IRC about people taking this seriously, but I think it's pretty awesome. Be proud!
I thought this was some kind of anti-nuclear weapons thing at first... good thing it wasn't. That would have seemed preachy.
sorry, but I think this is awesome, and kind of shows up your 'setting themes are bad' argument. this is a really good entry :)
Wow! I really loved this! The idea was cool, and the ending actually had a pretty big impact on me. :)

Pretty crazy. I wasn't quite sure what that was but it was pretty crazy.
I guess I do agree about settings making for bad themes, because you can just make any game and place it in that setting. I do think that several games used it well though. I guess you used it in reverse, where the setting was really out of this world even though there were some islands in there. Good show.
How do I start? After the warning screen I can see part of a map with a radar in the corner and a quarter of a sign that says "LEAR" and "ST" under it. . .

Had to read the comments to work out what you meant by "setting themes". Anyway...

I loved it. Very original. Any harder to control and it would have been frustrating, but you pitched it just right. Loved the 60s vibe.

My eyes are broken now, thanks a lot :)
Weird and good. In a weird way.

Well umm... that friggin sucked. That being said....
The Good - EXCELLENT use of theme, great graphics, decent use of sound, tho minimalist, kind of almost fun to play... kind of burned to look at...
The Bad - kind of burned to look at, terrible use of theme...
The Ugly - the theme.
I've never been so nauseous in my entire life
This is fantastic.  My favourite game of the competition.

description:
This is my submission to LD48.
You play a Dodo on the Island of Mauritius, trying to survive - WILL YOU MAKE IT? (Hint: probably no...).
Enjoy!
Download (First one is from google sites, second mirror supplied by ELI!! in hope it'll work... :-) )
Unzip to some directory and run "run.bat". Windows only, I'm afraid.
Be sure to read "readme.txt" if you have any problems.
The game was made using Visual C++ and the wonderful ClanLib.
Art was made using Paint.NET, GraphicsGale and Inkscape.
Music using Fruityloops and some old EMU soundfonts lying around on my hard drive.
Thanks!
Daniel
EDIT: I saw some people were having problems with OpenGL 2.
I fixed this and it now uses OpenGL 1.1 - Hope this helps! Thanks for the comments!
author: zdanielz
title: Mauritius
comments: I really liked this, and the dodo story's a great use of the theme.  I wouldn't have minded a larger island to try and survive in though.

This is a fantastic game!! The artwork and music are perfectly fitting for the theme and story. I especially loved the plump dodo and the soldier.

It's great that you created a whole game, and finished it too. Maybe making a more dramatic fate for the Dodo could improve the message.

Also, I found the gameplay a bit frustrating. (But I am bad at precisely-timed platformers, so maybe I'm not the one to ask.)

GREAT work, can't wait to see your future projects.
Now I know why the dodo went extinct... very hard platforming mechanics, but impressive style, man!
I like the art, and the music fit very nicely. The gameplay was a bit frustrating, but I guess that was the point... Nice work overall!
The movement is perhaps a bit too fast, but overall this was a very enjoyable game! I would definitely have liked some checkpoints here and there, though. ;)
Couldn't run due to no GL 2.0-capable hardware. I will abstain from rating so it won't affect your score.

Exception caught: This application requires OpenGL 2.0 or above. Yadda yadda OpenGL 1.1.0

GLView and other games say otherwise.
Good stuff, quite fun. I managed to make it all the way to the right end of the screen and killed myself on purpose. Could have maybe been a bit more complex in terms of play options, but well done.

This was far more fun than it should have been, I'm really glad you posted the OpenGL 1 version. Music is awesome despite the short loop, and the graphics are pretty sweet too. I actually died at the same time as reaching the end,so the ending text came up as I was falling off the screen, for added effect. Poor Dodo :(
I was about to post "cant make it work" whaen i suddenly started to her the music. But when i was playing, the sound like... crackled. But I enjoyed the game =)

description:
An experimental, minimalistic microgame about loneliness.
Hopefully the theme tie-in should be clear.
HINT: At the beginning of the game, you need to go UP.
NOTE: I DO plan on adding some minimalistic music at some point... for the time being, try playing the game while listening to a song you feel goes with the title :)
Congrats to everyone who submitted a game, or learned something, or had a good time :). I've seen some amazing looking stuff on the front page, and am really looking forward to playing as many of these games as I can. I love the community here. Best to everyone,
Jordan
author: Jordan Magnuson
title: Loneliness
comments:
I felt conditioned!  Towards the end I was properly anxious about whether or not it was worth the bother to try approach people - I usually ended up trying anyway.

The whole "screen starts scrolling once you're in the middle" thing confused me a lot at first - took three or four starts before I figured out that I was supposed to move up.
I love that Simon & Garfunkle song.

Nice idea, well executed. I liked seeing the way the different groups behaved - of course, knowing I could never take part for myself...

Later on I came across someone on their own. I thought maybe things would be different... no :'(

So I felt the mood which was great. I think the game could be more emotionally powerful with some music, even a fairly simple tune.
When the lone block comes towards you near the end and then runs away... that's rough.

Ha, I loved it. I half wanted to do something similar. Funny patterns sometimes, and the expected ending.

Music would have been great though.
Excellent depiction of the theme! I really loved the message of this.

Yay, pretentious art game! :)

Not much of a game, but does convey emotion quite nice. Music would be nice.

I like the idea, but I don't really agree with the "game". I really feel like it's more the other way around. It's not that everyone is avoiding the lonely person, but it's more that the lonely person is the one doing the avoiding. If that makes any sense. I would have liked it more if your job was to chase everyone away with pessimism and you like had a pessimism bar that went down over time unless you "fed" it somehow with like old french poetry and pretentious music or something like that (angst power ups?). Now that would have been a good depiction of loneliness!

description:
UPDATE: The php source code - which is very little actual code - is available at the source link below. I recommend against reading it, as the source contains spoilers, but go ahead if you want to know any of the answers. The rest of the source is just HTML and can be viewed through your browser.
---
I decided I wanted to make a simple web game for this contest. Instead, I tried to focus on making some content (with varying success). I didn't have too much time during the weekend, but I'm relatively happy with this anyhow. It was a fun game to make.
I do hope it's at least somewhat enjoyable. If it's too tricky, you can get hints by viewing each page's source. I'd enjoy seeing somebody complete the game, as the end screen is the part of the game I'm happiest with. :)
author: Morre
title: Islands: Through the Sweep of Stars
comments: Can't get past the Fear. Nice art!
Woo! This is very cool. I couldn't get past the skull place (even though I figured out how to view the hints) but I love the style.

Very cool idea. Reminds me of the try2hack kinda games :)

Some of the riddles seemed impossible, but after a while they all became obvious :)
Got stuck on fear.  Will have to think about it!
Loved the art style.  Gameplay was great (except for when I had to cheat!) and enjoyed the sense of triumph when I finally got the right answer.
This has an interesting feeling to it. It's neat to see you trying something so different. I hope it was a fun experience for you.

That was entertaining, and some of the riddles were really witty. Fear was my favorite, peril took me far, far longer than it should have. Short and sweet, with great pictures. I'm quite fond of the source-comments-as-hints system.
Got stuck on 'fear' as well, great graphics!

That would have been nice, turned into a Pretentious Art Game, with some delicate music and a minimum of interactivity (moving a guy around to get clues?) The drawings have a pretty distinctive style, would have like more!

Most of the questions were far too tricky to be answered without cheating. Perhaps basing them only on clues in the images would have been more interesting.

It has some charm though.

The graphics are very very nice. I especially liked the ending. The "gameplay" though is very simplistic, and the riddles were a bit arbitrary and didn't follow any pattern. I would love to see you do another series of these, or perhaps flesh it out into a graphic adventure.
These are way too hard for me. Nice art!
Haha, this was fun and quite original. Took me a while to get the last one. Duh! :)

Somewhat annoyingly, I found most of them too hard without the hint and then too easy with the hint.

Graphics are lovely; I wish there was some ambient music as well to create more atmosphere.
Interesting. Nice riddles. Needs to be longer, though.
Stuck on fear. Still don't understand the first island :(.

Love it! I got stuck on the island of peril. Beautiful artwork, great execution. I think maybe there should be a hint somewhere that you can look at the source code for a hint. I played this a couple times before and couldn't get past the first screen, so I didn't want to rate it. But the hints you have structured are really just that, hints. My fave was the Island of Fear.

I have no idea what to answer on the island of fear. Even with the hint.
Nice, quite different idea. But getting stuck is basically the end of the game.

AH! I GET IT NOW!
You had some devilish little riddles in there.
The answer to FEAR was so awesome. Took me a while.

Love the art. The riddles were mostly too oblique for me, I got some of them, some by guessing, but mostly had to cheat.

The final screen was great, love to see that on a t-shirt. :)

Nice twist on the theme, too.

description: You are a super floating island super explorer! Adventure through SIX (count 'em!) levels in search of a palm tree to call your own! Warp from island to island through the power of something! Precarious platforming! Useless coins! YEAH!
author: Hinchy
title: Wow, Islands And Stuff!!
comments: Very nice platformer. Nothing really innovative, but fun.
Very cool, simple but it works. I really liked the idea of the whole "transporting orbs". Some of the plants' sprites were buggy for me, showing a black line on the top. Other than that, great game.

Finished it! I liked it, but I thought it took a while to get going, and felt a bit over long, maybe. 

I liked it overall, though. Feels very polished and complete! Liked the graphics and the music too. There's a lot here for 48 hours. :)
Very enjoyable! The level design was mostly very good, and you had managed to make the game feel fun to play. :)
Great music, and nice graphics. Decent gameplay mechanics too.

Very solid game! Not particularely innovative, but really good fun.

Hint: When I saw the first time "YOU WON" I thought the whole game is done ;)
I enjoyed the levels, and was pleasantly surprised when the night-time lighting effect kicked in. The being moved around when passing a checkpoint worked really well.
Awesome amount of content done in so little time. The game really has a polished feel. Very nice.

I really liked it. Simple and fun. I agree it's a lot of content. Excellent music. In my opinion, the only thing that could be better is the collision detection, but you don't even notice when playing because it's a great game. Congratulations.
Cool little game, but like others have said, it's not all that innovative. Not much to do with islands, either... but the music was very island-y. Overall good job!

Tehee. That was cute. Nothing new, but well done.
The Good - Graphics where, for the most part, good looking,audio felt appropriate, and the level design was mostly pretty rad. I also liked the lack of consequence for dying, that was good considering...
The Bad - Leaps of faith frequently ended in death, except for the times they ended in orbs, or switches.... groan.
The Ugly - Rotated sprites had terribly anti aliasing. Im sure that was just because of the program you used, and I am guilty of using rotation to save time too, but god that looked bad.
Very good music and nice graphics

Nice platformer. The little teleport bubbles didn't really add anything to the gameplay, and the made the layout more confusing and less linear.

description:
Phew, making an RTS in 48 hours is hard.
Tiny Armada is a quick RTS game that is played entirely with boats, trading between colonies on the different islands for wealth and fighting for control of the trade routes.
[HOW TO PLAY]
Mouse to select and order your units.
Select your capital to train additional units.
Merchants provide income over time when ordered to a small colony, galleys fight enemy ships and capture cities for you.
Destroying an enemy capital will give you control over that player's units.
There is no win screen. Or a lose screen. When either of these situations arise, you may press R to restart.
Also, if the random map generator gives you a stupid map, feel free to restart.
I'll probably be making a postcompo version that has a lot more polish and works without as many minor hiccups. Also, optimizing.
In response to questions that I assume are being asked in secret: You are blue. Fire does not hurt units, it is merely an indicator of hurt. There is no point in owning a colony other than feeling powerful. If you do not build any merchants at the beginning, you will probably fail. If a colony is inland it is useless.
The source can be run with the crossplatform Love engine, which is a very small download at http://love2d.org/download
To view the source files: the .love file is actually a .zip file, and can be renamed and opened as such.
Some aspects of the game are not very optimized, and so it may run slowly on weaker/older machines. Let me know if you're having any problems running it.

Wow, what a jackass... the previous uncompressed version contained the data for the engine test I sent out ( proof - http://www.stuckiegamez.co.uk/gamez/ludumdare/ld17/yargh-44.zip is the original demo on hour 44, it contains the same script set as this uncompressed version which was linked till two mins ago - http://www.stuckiegamez.co.uk/gamez/ludumdare/ld17/yargh-uncompressed.zip )
Thanks to shockedfrog for pointing it out!
What you can do, is mix and match the exes with the ( now four ) different zips, and it'll all work regardless.. so you could have, for instance, switched the virus scanner twitchy compressed exe in the original release, with the uncompressed one and it'd work fine. The engine has zero game logic, it's all in script so it wouldn't matter.
I've now updated the Uncompressed link with that containing the uncompressed exe PLUS the actual released data set.. and I've properly beat myself about the head for my stupidity.. perhaps next LD I'll actually release something without any bugger ups!
== UPDATE 2 ==
== UPDATE ==
I've added an uncompressed Win32 binary release as some virus scanners have been throwing hissy fits. I can only assume this is due to running the binary through UPX to compress it.
If there are any other issues, please let me know :)
== UPDATE ==
The one mega zip contains all data, an AMD64 Linux binary and a Win32 binary.
Engine source changes shall be up shortly once I get it committed to the branch. -- edit: They're up now, you can browse here: http://www2.xp-dev.com/sc/browse/42754/ or grab direct from SVN: http://svn2.xp-dev.com/svn/stuckie-SGZEngine/
Reposting the ReadMe here ( it's a ReadMe for a reason ;) )
YARGH! - Shake Yer Booty!
=========================
It's not quite complete.. there's a number of things missing but I've spent most of this weekend fighting with my engine and chasing obscure list bugs, sadly.
I'm releasing as is; there's still a lot there and it's amusing to see just how vicious the computer can actually be at times.
It's sheer bedlam!
Feel free to fiddle with the scripts as well ;)
I did atleast fix the bug that they'd go and absolutely destroy all the forts and mines immediately after starting ;)
Granted, you can't pillage the mines or forts ( it refused to pick up the buttons for some reason ) but hopefully this'll be a quick fix later.
I've enjoyed this Ludum Dare.. it's been a fun game to work on :)
Engine issues aside, of course...
Anyway, brief controls:
Left Click on your ship to select it.
Right Click moves it.
Arrow Keys or moving the mouse to the edge of the screen pans the camera.
While a unit is selected:
Hold LEFT Control and Right click an enemy unit to attack it.
Hold LEFT Shife and Right click on the ground to board/disembark from a ship ( depending on whether you're controlling a ship or man at the time )
Apologies that I didn't get this finished as much as I'd have liked...
And I shall say the usual - I'll try and continue it where possible!
Hope you at least enjoy wandering around and seeing the computer cause mayhem ;)
Oh, and you can change the screen resolution in the data/scripts/config.sgz ( just a text file )
640x480 is a bit cramped, 1024x768 was what it was developed in, but I'm sure you can ramp it up if you like.
Thanks :)
Steven Campbell

In the long run getting kinda boring, but still a solid game for 48 hours.
Great graphics and sound effects. Multiplayer would be great. I believe that the control scheme could be simplified.

I was sure the audio was music! It syncopated pretty well, but grated a bit.

Nice graphics. Things jumped around a little, hard to tell what was on purpose and what was a bug.
Quite a good entry that would have been perfect with just a bit more gameplay. I loved the style of this and the theme, I just found myself relatively bored by the end.
I liked the graphics and the concept, but had the same problems with the audio and understanding what exactly was going on with the map and the hook and the marking of the spot.
Man, this is pretty hard. It's possible, but challenging. Great innovation with the graphics, too. Nice work!

description:
The king has commanded you, a daring pirate, to gather gold for him.
He has given you 3 days to complete this mighty task.
You must slay monsters and other pirate ships in order to collect collect gold, and return to the king before time is up!
Controls
Arrow Keys: Move
Y/N/Enter: Selections
F4: Full Screen
Esc: Quit
Pageup: Speed game up (sometimes helpful for laptops)
Pagedown: Slow game down
See included .txt file for full instructions.
Enjoy!
author: Haighstrom
title: Simon Haigh's Pirates!
comments:
The "night" effect was very sudden and unexpected.
The gameplay seemed to be just traveling in circles looking for targets, no skill or strategy involved and it wasn't fast paced enough to be mindless fun.
Still, leveling up still has that mystical appeal, and getting stronger feels like an accomplishment.
I can't comment on the art if you didn't make it.

I also found the "night" effect to be jarring. I found it fast paced enough to be "mindless" fun. Having enemies give the same amount of experience gain regardless of the level difference from the player was actually really good - otherwise the order in which viable targets were found would matter too much.

Uhh, well, LD is a solo competition, you're meant to do all the art and music yourself (even if it hurts!).  So this doesn't fall within the spirit or the letter of the rules.

It's a shame though, because aside from that it is kinda cool.
There are a few flaws (generated monster/chests that can't be reached) but all in all it was a very good game. I would you continue this one, it could be a very good game once polished.

Could be quite nice if some of its flaws are mended: A tad to slow, a bit more challenge and diversity.
Right now you're mostly travelling about and looking for lower numbers.
Can't vote on graphics and audio.

I enjoyed the game. The leveling up was fun and I managed to kill the ogre near the center and get 9240 gold in total. Still I think the game would need to have some sort of enemies which can actually hurt you or something like that. Maybe even a multiplayer real time version :)

I enjoyed this a lot - the basic mechanic is really fun and unique, like a statistical version of Katamari Damacy. :) Although the art and music are really good, please make your own stuff next time. :(

I found the gameplay quite fun! It could be definitely made better with less running around, though. As others have said, this is a solo thing, so even though the musics are great, I guess I can't rate them.
Simple, but fun. Nice music/art also, but I can't rate you on it since you didn't do it :/

description:
Its a pirate tycoon game, much like the original Sid Meiers's Pirates. To play- Buy and sell from the market menu, move to different islands from the travel menu, upgrade your ship in the town menu.
There is also a readme file included with the game.
*IMPORTANT!!!*
To play a love game- Either drag the game (.love file) on to the love.exe or double click the game file and choose Love.exe as the program to run it. If you just click the love.exe you will get a tank. That is not the game. You must run the .love file
I was unable to test it on Linux or Mac, but Love is built cross compatible, so it should work.
*Please submit any bugs you find! My development team and I want to continue this project.*
author: Tyler
title: Piratey Tycoon
comments:
It's mentioned above, but I'll mention it here:
Love.exe is for the framework, and the .love is the game file.  To run the game, open the .love file with the love.exe (drag the .love onto the love.exe)
Needs less not letting me click the trade button. D:

I basically understood it, but this game is like information overload. I desperately needed some kind of price tracker so that I can tell whether I'm getting a good deal without doing homework. I wasn't expecting to die when I did.

A bit hard to get into. You should have instructions that you can read at your leisure instead of scrolling by slowly. Trading doesn't feel very piratey. Seems to me like pirates were the enemy here. Also, you should make an executable that runs your game directly, or at least a batch file to run it for you. I'm not sure everybody gets how to run the game.
Good show. I think with some tweaking this could be a lot of fun.
I agree with the others, it was a bit dry as an experience. You had managed to get a lot into it, though!
Sadly, it didn't seem to work for me. I just got a blank white window titled 'Lost'. And yes, I followed the instructions above, both types. I'll come back and try it later.

I enjoyed this. It was like playing the auction house in WoW. I wish there was some sort of minimap or something that helps you when you're out in open seas. It was a little slow while figuring it out, but I found myself staring and the sell prices, poised and ready to strike!

I thought it was interesting how all the numbers updated in real time as I looked at the screen. (It was a bit strange when it happened during a battle at sea, though.)

Like Tom 7, I found myself wishing for some kind of aid to help me know if I was getting a good deal or not - or at least remind me what price I paid for the goods that I was about to sell, so I could tell if I was making a profit.
Like philomory, "I just got a blank white window titled 'Lost'." It doesn't seem like I'm missing much.

The game took awhile to get into (to get to know which is a good price and which is a bad one). After that it was quite easy. Though I mainly just used steel, iron and silver since they had highest profits and everything seemed to take equal storage amount.

I think this is a game I played most times and longest of the ones I've tried so far (only about 15). I generally bought silver for less than 250, steel and iron for less than 200. Usually they can be sold for 300-400.

Still the sea battles seemed very hard and I died many times and had to start from the beginning. Was there anything that could be gained from winning a battle? Or should I have just always ran?
Gets completely unresponsive, I get 0.1 FPS in the menu already, when I click onto an option the app gets hung (not in the good sense).

Couldn't really get into it. Hard to figure out what to do.. needs some sort of real tutorial or better yet, a progression where it starts off really simple and adds stuff/items/options slowly.

Some great names for the boats and crew, though. With some tuning and especially a LOT of tuning on the learning curve, could be a lot of fun.

description:
Greetings. This is a game which I'd abandoned after several hours of work, and then suddenly decided to un-abandon after an even longer duration. It is inspired primarily by the Mega Man series and the NES game Battle Kid: Fortress of Peril, and secondarily by Knytt Stories. It is, at the moment, an abbreviated version of a somewhat larger game I would like to make some day.
EDIT: If you're having some trouble, note that you can fire in 8 directions. (This is easier if you hold Shift.)
author: L
title: On an Iron Isle
comments:
This is a beautiful little game.
BUT MY GOLLY IT'S HARD.

I couldn't work my way to the end, but I'll give it another go in a few days. I'll repost my comments when I do.
This was a bit too hard to be enjoyable, but I found it a good fan game nontheless.
I really love the death effect!  It makes me not want mind dying cos it looks so cool

This game was like.. Mega Man in terms of difficulty.  But it made getting past enemies a challenge, which makes it more fun.  The recap of my gameplay was:  evaluate bad guy, die, kill bad guy, move onto next, evaluate, die, repeat infinitely.  

With that being said, it was fun until I got tired of dying.
Really amazing style, hard to believe you did this in the amount of time you say. I'm terrible at it though, and can't make it past the first screenful of enemies as the last dude gets me every time.
Two screens and then i get tired to die. =(

The graphics are fantastic!!! I am fascinated by the style, especially the tiles and the death effect.

Gameplay is prohibitively hard, however. I didn't make it past the third screen, even after killing the first snails

ps. it looks like you meant to add more underwater screens? It was so surprising that I didn't die outright when I explored there. Such a wonderful touch.
Very hard indeed. The aiming system is quite difficult to use, but the effects sure looked cool!

Hole feck, it's hard.
Well done, but hard. I loved the dying animation.
I was unable to locate the sourcecode for your game.

Wow, for real, I couldn't get past the first room of badguys.  I seem to be in good company on that.  Best I did was to get to the last one.  I think I hit him 3 times once, so close.  The death was cool, though.  Definitely a vote for turning down the difficulty.  I've played Mega Man, and this sir, is no Mega Man.

It's so hard! I loved the graphics and sound, the counting down battery and the atmosphere were right from the start, and I really wanted to climb the tower (after verifying that the underwater is not hospitable). I love how my heart robot does flips if I jump far, or how I explode when I die. But I don't like dying. I finally got to the third room with baddies, but got killed when I fell back down to avoid a fireball, back onto the crab I had just killed! Arg! The most frustrating thing about the rooms is not so much that they're hard, but you have to shoot the crabs so many times that there's lots of waiting for them to step on cracks to do it safely. If it was just about performing difficult maneuvers it would be fun to try, but the hard stuff with waiting in between encourages me to be reckless and impatient, which is frustrating. I didn't give up on most of the LD17 games I played, so this must be one of the hardest. :) Still, I liked it. Plays really smooth.

There was some nice touches here, but, GAH, the enemies are b-r-u-t-a-l!

Liked what happened when I fell off the island.  Didn't understand the pink things in the slightest.  The death animation terrified me the first time I saw it.

for an semi-abandoned game I've got to so congratulations, you've made a really smooth fluid platformer, the motion and animation is great for falling from great heights, the only thing I would say is the enemies take a lot of hits, but the game itself, superb! Really was like megaman, so very difficult :P

description: Battle against the devilish Red Tribe amongst the islands that surround your home! Lead the Yellow Tribe to victory, each time on a (almost) totally random map!
author: Staggy
title: Island Warz
comments:
Cool concept!

It's very tough, too. Or maybe I just suck?

Hmn! I had some trouble understanding what was going on (now I know what it feels like; everybody is saying the same thing about my game :-) However it seems like I can move ships to an island from my home island, but the island I move to doesn't really become mine? Kudos for random map generation! =)
Son of Galcon. Well, it's obviously still unfinished, but it's still good fun for a couple of minutes and it's a good use of the theme.

Holy Misbalance, Batman! :)
I don't stand a chance against the computer, he overwhelms me every time.
Nice idea though, a bit more balancing and maybe de-I the AI a bit.
Nice touch of strategy. The game wasn't very hard, and it seemed that occasionally the inhabitants on my islands decreased instead of rising as I sent more boats on them.

kind of like Galcon. I guess it's a genre now.

Fun, but a little unpolished. Quite a few of the levels I got were pretty bunched up and overlapping which made them hard to play. Still, the random levels worked pretty well and was a good fit for the theme.

I would have liked a better explanation than "sacred sailing routes" for the fixed paths -- maybe draw coral where you can't go or something...

I can't win - why is it that the islands next to me have huge populations but the bot's seem to be easy peasy? is this to make it more difficult. Also there are bugs where somehow a ship can go past an already populated island, allowing the bot to get past my defense and hit a supplier island in the back, completely screwing my chances even more. Pretty fun overall though.

Not entirely sure how this is supposed to work; is there a difference between the islands where I get bases (and can thus send more guys forwards) and those where I don't? When the red tribe is gone, am I supposed to win? Also, once there was an island with no routes.

description:
This is my first entry. I learned a lot and I can't wait to do another one, although I'll have to wait the next one out. Good luck everyone!
EDIT: here's an alternate download link in case you can not download the file:
http://www.mediafire.com/file/24zrmj52eur/island_survivor.zip
EDIT: Please note, you can win the game! You can find water from the crates as well as springs within the island if you explore the island enough.
author: shady1024
title: Island Survivor
comments: Fun little title, would love to have seen it a little more developed but I enjoyed what you'd done so far.
You have to install the aplication running setup.
Interesting I haven't seen more of this classic approach to islands. Ran our of water and died though... Not possible to win. Still I liked what you got so far. I liked breaking the boxes.

Yep, this is a winnable game.

I liked the sounds (drinking, eating) and the music riff that played. I guess more sounds would have rounded it off.

I was going to mention the extremely short look-ahead distance, but seeing as there are no enemies or dangers to speak of, I guess it's not that important. I assume you mean to keep crates and berries more surprising.

Yay, all I needed to do is drink from the canteen often enough and voila, I was suddenly saved :)
I would like to see where you wanted to go with this, more items, more possibilities, etc...

I won easily!  I think it's because I happened to stumble across two canteens and a fishing pole in moments.  That's one huge island.  The thing I really didn't like was that the camera didn't scroll until you were about a millimeter from the screen edge.  That was maddening.
I love that you put fishing in your game!! There's something about digital fishing that is just entertaining...

description:
Defend the island from the invaders in longboats!
Select a structure, and hit the B key to spawn a unit.
Each unit costs a specific amount of resources.
Collect resources with villagers, and fight off foes with militia.
TIPS:
Start off by buying all the villagers you can with the starting resources, and then target getting rock and wood to make as many villagers as you can. Keep doing this until you're struggling with your militia, and need to create more.
Keeping a single militia near each boat point so that dropped off enemy militia don't attack your villagers.
Certain resources can get crowded, and villagers will spend a lot of time trying to get a space around the resource, rather than actually collecting the resource. It is advised to move villagers away from these overcrowded resources onto other nearby resources.
author: Gobo
title: Island Defender
comments: The game is fairly difficult. I like the starcraft like feel it has with a different type of play.
Very good for the time give, only wish you had added a little more variation

I left "fun" n/a, because I'm not really the best to judge "fun" of an RTS (I don't like them). =p I like what you accomplished though. The graphics were ok, though it was tough to see what was going on in the battles. Multi-select would have been nice. Good job overall.

The .zip file doesn't count was a Web application, hehe. ;)

Very ambitious for a 48h compo! Works quite nicely, though those darn enemies just ignored my soldiers while killing my poor peasants!

Impressive for 48 hours! Selecting more than one enemy would've been nice (although you can select more than one if they overlap).
Needs sounds!

Wasn't sure which file was the game at first.
It's rather awkward to play. Units appear to be idle when they are gathering resources and attacking. Selection of units is limited to point and click, no way to select multiple units unless they are on top of each other in which case you probably only want to select one of them anyways.

description:
This game was made as a Glorious Trainwreck in the last two hours of LD17 using Unity 3D. Sound effects made with Sfxr, music with Musagi, textures with Paint.Net.
Your goal is to roll a ball as far as you can across rickety platforms in the water without falling in. You have to move quickly, because the platforms will tip over.
Here's my timelapse video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pvvT9Xcr4nQ
Controls:
WASD or arrow keys to move, Spacebar to jump.
author: pekuja
title: Island Balance
comments: For being made in just two hours it's pretty nice. But I would like to see your other strategy game finished. I enjoyed the prototype you uploaded.
Haha, You should totally tell about the jump button! ;D Quite fun, but indeed, requires more meat.
Jump button very rarely chooses to work in the Windows version for some reason. The web one works quite well though. Got as far as 114, is there a max possible score/'end'?

Hah, well it was quite amusing, and certainly pretty great for a two hour trainwreck style thing.  As so often with physics-y based things the simulation causes the gameplay to suffer significantly.  It's just too hard to predict the causes+reactions to get all that much fun from it.
Wow, it's actually pretty fun for being made in two hours. But, a bit too frustrating.
Like it's namesake the trainwreck, you can't look away. Oddly compelling for a two hour game, but, I'd still like to see the entry you had been planning to do, fleshed out.

I really enjoyed that, great job.
And only 2 hours?!
well for 2 hours its definitely something, and is interesting in some ways but I couldnt find a place where I enjoyed playing it I'm afraid ^_^;

Obviously a great game for only 2 hours. Very impressive, good idea and mechanic, even with music (despite being repetitive).

Hoping to see a stronger entry next time.

I think that with some more control and difficulty tweaking this trainwreck would be a really good game.

I tried your last RTS build too. It looked good. I know what you mean about getting paralysed because you want to do something with the game but you know it can't be finished in time.
Cool but... Yearrrgh! The spacebar often fails to jump for me! Other than that I like it. Might be more fun if the ball was bouncier/lighter/faster...

Really good for two hours. 
The controls are rough (Web), you basically have to jump yourself to speed when starting out. The ball speeds up too slow. If you just roll you sink.
Friggin hard, but neat idea. Could use some polish, but good. Nice music :)
Pretty fun little diversion - good work for two hours. I enjoyed it.

I like it very much! And even it was that simple it was very challanging. Ok the music is still killing my brain, but the game was excellent. Nevertheless I didn't get more than 60 points... Maybe later :D
Pretty fun. I would have liked it even if it was done in 48 hours.

description:
A game where you control a large head that blows on volcanic ash clouds to bring down planes.
Edit: Sorry about the controls being awful. I think the sensitivity varies a lot from person to person.
author: Rolf
title: Iceland and the volcanic ASH of DOOM
comments: Love the graphics , the gameplay shows promise and is almost very captivating. Sound would have made it ten times better, but all in all, a solid production!
Mouse goes reeeally slow on my computer, not sure if it's normal or not, seems quite hard this way tho. Interesting and unique idea, pretty good gfx. Funny too!
I found the controls pretty annoying, and not working as expected. Other than that, fun and topical idea!
The controls were brutal, which is unfortunate because the core gameplay would have been fun!
Sound would have helped a lot. Fun idea though.
One of the bizarre games, yet fitting for the theme (and current events). Very good idea, but it gets old very fast.
Yes, the controls are tricky. Funny idea, and otherwise good implementation!

The mouse is incredibly slow, I had to restart to see that you actually have to move left/right to turn around.
Some other control scheme would've worked wonders.
This looks promising, but as it is, it's a little repetitive. With some extra powers, abilities, powerups, etc. this could be even better.
Nice game,...but I have to admit that I crashed many planes. And no, it was not by accident :D! Good job,...
Rather awkward to control, but an amusing concept.  Props for doing something different with unity :)
Tricky to control and needs sound, but it's SO TOPICAL!!!

description: Unfinished but playable... it was a good time! Src included in zip, or visit ld48jovoc on google code.
author: jovoc
title: Galapagos
comments: I was looking forward to playing this, but unfortunately it refuses to run on my laptop! :( Amazing work with the graphics though, I totally approve of the direction you've going here! :)
Aw dang, it looks so lovely, i dig that style. Really a shame that there isn't much of a game yet. I expect you to finish that ;)
I also expect you to finish it, especially because the game moves exactly like I had it in mind after seeing the screenshots. Also the music is neat!

Nice fresh graphics approach!!! The turn-based aspect got to me, though. I managed to get trapped between two pink-animals on a narrow bridge. (My luck.)

It would be interesting to see where this goes. Great music!
I can't play it, but the graphics and music are cool

Really nice looking game, the story intriqued me to bad there is no ending. Music and sound is good, the pigs (monsters) are really annoying when they block your path, but no big deal. I would love for this game to be completed.

I think you had the same problem making your game that I did; trying to jam out a story can take a lot of time, which is something we don't have for LDs.  The game looks great though; looking forward to seeing future use of this style and engine.
Wow,...this could have been a real blockbuster,...the whole surrounding feels just right! But as belbeeno said, it's hard to also create a story in that short period...

I would love to see this game finished. Even though it is unfinished I had fun just walking around and talking to people.
Great graphics and music.
Hello, It doesn't run in my notebook.. I wil try in a a different computer later.

The pig AI seems bent on getting in your way.

Great graphics and humorous start to the story!
Looks like a good start to something. Cool music.
It crashes within the first 5 seconds of play. Looks nice, and the music, from the first 5 seconds, seems pretty good... just doesnt run.

Wow, the graphics are so cool! I like the music too. I'd love to play this game, but in its unfinished state it's at best a teaser. :) What is up with those lumps, anyway? They just wanna get in my way?
Hope you finish it. I enjoyed what was there!

description:
Move through a series of dream islands on a journey through memories of a past relationship.
EDIT: Added an improved version I've been working on since the competition.
author: Perrin
title: Dreams of how we once were
comments: Definitely not a video, and not a traditional game..but an interactive story. Which I still categorize as a "video game". I enjoyed it, for what it's worth.

Your game was more of a video than a game. There was little game play, and it seemed to tell more of a story then have gameplay. I would suggest next LD to make your scope smaller and add more gameplay.
The final two stages were excellently done.
I see where you were going with this one, but I didn't like the lack of gameplay. And lol @ the rainbows
This game has some really really great moments, which I really enjoyed.  Played through to the end - was much longer than I expected.
I didn't enjoy it, probably because I didn't understand it :( (I hope that was the reason) and is a bit slow.

Hope you had a good time with unity - I really enjoyed the starting portion of this, and in general liked the architectural aspects.  I liked jumping into the water the first time.  At some point I lost interest in the story - the lines it followed were, to me, a little clichÃ©d.

Anyway, good work

An interesting experiment. I can see how this could be quite an evocative medium for an art game, exploring environments and being given snippets of emotional recollections regarding them. Not sure exactly how the islands tie in, except to structure the story into chapters, but I'll give you the benefit of the doubt on that.

My main problem with it is that when you fall, it respawns you back at the beginning. A few islands in, I stepped back to take a better look at something and fell off the edge, and didn't feel like walking back through everything I'd already seen just to get to where I was. Like walking through a door at a museum, finding you're back at the entrance, and the door has locked behind you.

This came out really well - islands four and five, especially.

I played this with country music in the background.

Was a little too much video and not enough gameplay.  With that said, I still liked it.  The emotional impact was there and felt like I was a peering into the life of another person.  

Falling was a big pain, though.  Having to go all the way back to the beginning when falling off almost deterred me from completing.

Like Xopods said, the concept was interesting, albeit not a game, the way you exposed the story made me craving for more and so I kept going on.
Some problems though, the mouse sensivity (I don't know if I can edit it) was WAY too high, which made me fall one or two times. It's like an YouTube video, where you wan't to rewind it only a bit, and then it starts all over the beginning.
Also, the lack of sound made it harder to have any emotional attachment to the story, maybe next time you should think about that.

At last, WONDERFUL work with the skies and textures, those were REAL nice artworks.

Novel idea, and despite the wonky movement, I did keep playing to see what the next snippet would be.  It would be interesting to see a polished take on the concept. In a way, though, I think trying to add much more "game" might actually detract from it.

Really did not like that this was a huge mass of default unity things (like the palm trees, really integral parts of the artwork and you didn't make them.  I drew my own palm trees!).  The movement was also very bad.  Really could have used some emphasis on making the experience smooth and usable, not just getting the 'art stuff' in front of the player.
You're dark man. Very very dark.

Interesting concept, not really game, rather a story.

And a few flaws: Falling off somewhere puts you back at the current chapter. Urgh. 

Also, half of the textures and palms seem to be premade stuff. Not good in LD.
umm.... ok that weirded me out. looks like you did alot of work though.

I really liked some of the scenes, specifically the one where they grew apart (with the couch then the two seats) and how the world was turned upside down, but the earlier scenes didn't seem to be very interesting. I liked the theme implementation and the use of projectors, but this is a game where 'atmospheric' music is a requisite in my opinion. Overall interesting and well put together but missing some stuff key to the experience that was trying to be delivered.

description:
My first Ludum Dare entry ever. This probably got about 26-28 hours of actual hands-on work. Unity is the best thing. :D
In this game you play an explorer in the Age of Sail. Outfit your ship and crew and set sail in search of uncharted islands, buried treasure, and mythical creatures.
It's kind of a short-form roguelike, I suppose. I didn't get to make as many events as I wanted to before the deadline, so I'll have to flesh that out in a later version. Event variety really makes all the difference, here.
-Josh
http://www.third-helix.com
twitter.com/invicticide
author: invicticide
title: Conquistador
comments:
Kind of an obvious concept to work with, but a fun one. In a way, going obvious is in itself original - I've seen more sky islands (my own game included) than water islands.

Obviously, the game could use improved graphics and, as you say yourself, more events, better balance, etc., but it's a good start. Reminds me of Strange Adventures in Infinite Space, which isn't a bad thing. I hope you continue to work on it now that LD is over!
Dinosaur island was a nice surprise.

Good start. Has potential, but a little too random right now. I thought it odd that it always asked me "do you want to dig up the treasure?", "do you want to fight pirates?". The answer seems a tad obvious.
I must admit that the load-out screen almost made me put off playing this indefinitely, but once I spotted the 'default' button, I was able to play about and enjoy myself.
Very nice.  I liked the cutscene graphics and the overall game is solid for a weekend effort.  The piano music was a nice choice, too.
Thank you for the default load-out button!
Yay for the Priests! My team only had priests and they rock. Priest Pirates arrgggg!!!!

Pretty cool, I met a wide variety of unfortunate ends :) 

Despite the description, I always brought a priest just in case...
Hehe, nice! The humor gives it a lot of extra points.
LOL I found a dinosaur. This game was quite entertaining, but unfortunately I always had trouble outrunning storms.

Good game. Is there a goal actually? I tried to explore the full map but usually the crew mutinied before. There's not too much you can do against that?

More events, bigger map!

The load-out was a little too complicated and didn't feel important enough.  The events felt pretty brutal and arbitrary, without deep tactics..  Having said all that I did enjoy pottering about quite a bit, and there's a lot of potential here.

description:
The goal of Dare Islands is to goal the red boats into the red goal zone and the green boats into the green goal zone. The boats cannot be controlled directly, but the water currents can be changed by growing and removing islands. The left mouse button grows and and the right one removes it. If the boats hit land or enter the wrong goal zone, then a life is used.
The game requires .NET 3.5 Framework and some CPU speed. The code was done with F# and the Visual Studio 2008 Shell (with the F# plugin) as the IDE. The fluid simulation is a simple implementation of the Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM).
Sources are included in the main package. If the direct download link doesn't work, try downloading from the website.
author: XMunkki
title: Dare Islands
comments: Wow, that's an awesome idea, and a neat piece of technology. Definitely one of the more creative games around. I ended up funneling all traffic into one small area and selectively built/destroyed a "gate" island to deflect the boats depending on the color.
Interesting, but I think I'd have enjoyed it more if it had a slightly faster pace
The mechanics are very cool, but the game doesn't have a lot of variety with time. Some variety in what you have to handle or check points to give a sense of accomplishment would've been nice.
The simplicity in this game makes it worth it to me. You  did a great job at implementing a small project scope and making it work.

quoting fydo:
"Cool idea! 5 stars for innovation! :D"
Really, really cool! Needs some kind of balance for the gameplay. Great that you made an entire fluid simulation in a weekend.
Simple and fun. I believe it has a lot of potential to become a full game if you add some variety to the gameplay. Congratulations.

GREAT TECH!

Needs some audio, though. I'd also like to see some refinement in island placement. THIS IS PRETTY COOL.
Cool tech, though a bit hard to actually play. This has potential, keep going on this one :)
Nifty idea! Leaves a lot of strategy options. It'd be interesting to see this built into a full fledged game.

A bit slow to be fun, Good idea though.
For some reason the exe file didn't have any permissions which confused wine a bit.
A great idea, proved a little difficult, but wow, such an amazing idea and gameplay mechanic, very innovative!

Very inventive gameplay, nicely thematic. Bonus points for being high-tech and using ML. :) The game's pretty hard. My best strategy was to write off mixed groups of boats and trap them in lagoons without killing them, though it was hard to predict when they'd become "stuck" and die. I think it would have been better if the two colors of boats had different physical properties so it was possible to separate groups, or somehow to regain lives, because otherwise the game is always getting into a higher-entropy state. Hi-score 60

description:
Running the game:
OS X: Just double-click Capsize!.app
Windows: Double-click Capsize!.bat
Linux/Source: You'll need to get the dependencies yourself, sorry. First, have ruby and rubygems, then:
gem install gosu
gem install chipmunk-ffi
Download and install chipmunk: http://files.slembcke.net/chipmunk/release/ChipmunkLatest.tgz
Then, cd into the game's folder, and:
ruby LD17.rb
About:
This game, which was inspired by recent comments made by a certain Congressman on the House Armed Services Committee, does not reflect any particular political beliefs, other than perhaps the belief that people sometimes say really, really dumb things. About islands.
Objective:
The object is to keep the island of Guam from capsizing for as long as possible. You accumulate points over time - more points the more stuff is on the island. Stuff will be air dropped whether you like it or not; you can call in a new building by left-clicking, or a soldier by right-clicking. You lose points if a soldier drowns, and the game ends when the island capsizes.
Wish List:
There was supposed to be more, like ordering soldiers to build or destroy buildings, or build flotation devices, but, I couldn't get there in time. There was also supposed to be a song, but I didn't allot enough time to learn to use GarageBand - if you sit at the title screen long enough, you can hear some of the samples I was going to use.
Known Bugs:
There's a bug with the soldiers where when they drown, they still move around, oops. This can lead to them 'drowning' over and over again, and you losing points for it each time. Ah, well.
Controls:
Left click drops a building, right click a soldier. Escape quits
Enjoy!
author: philomory
title: Capsize! feat Rep. Johnson vs. DJ Admiral
comments: WTF even with the instruction I can't figure what to do. Left and right click ? I can't guess if I do anything. Are the things dropped from air mine ?

Hey, a Ruby entry! Good work!

I enjoyed the concept. One of the voice samples kept repeating (I guess it was the bug you mentioned about the soldiers failing to die), which got a bit annoying.

WHOA MAN! I LOVE THIS GAME!
MY FAVE SO FAR!
SO WACKY! SO GOOOOOD!
SOOOOO SOOOO GOOOOOD!

1) Awesome music

3) Cool concept / story

5) LAZER BEARS!!!!!!

Made at the Cambridge meet up! My game from day one didn't work out (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DcHihVVheM8), so I started from scratch on Sunday morning.

author: Terry
title: Radio Silence
comments: Had an awesome atmosphere. Also liked the underwater effect.

Sweet audio experience. 

I wouldn't have hated more visual help in regards to finding the sound emitting items, though. It wasn't always clear to me in which direction I needed to go (I was using headphones, better sound setup would have helped perhaps?)
Nicely done. Was there a win condition, or did I just not find all the radios?
Love the audio, and going for dark and dreary instead of the tropical paradise.
Very dark and atmospheric experience. Also yay for the Cambridge meetup!
I never found the last trinket - I wandered around but couldn't hear anything.  I liked exploring.

Just want to say that I did manage to find all the radios, through a combination of headphones, jumping and looking for odd specks in the distance, and avoiding revisiting places I've already been. Nicely done.

I only have one working headphone where I played this and it was probably a better experience than playing with both. Love pretentious art games because they give a glimpse into what could be done with game atmosphere going forward. That said this would've been a much more fun game if it didn't have any visuals and instead used audio cues to signify blockages and whatnot.

I really liked this one, it was definitely a memorable experience. reminded me of WHICH by Mike Inel actually, but mostly because of the dark view when in the water.
I wonder if its odd I found this game quite relaxing...
Oww my frickin ears! Some of those radio frequencies are brutal! I definitely liked the atmosphere you built up. Great to see you dabbling with Unity. :)

One thing I would suggest: I tried using headphones to help search for the trinkets, but I found that the levels for the water sounds and the radio sounds could have used some tuning (pun); either lowering the splash sound volume or lowering the roll-off factor may have helped, though you want to be careful with the latter as it would cause all the radio frequencies to meld together which could be interesting but would definitely sound terrible at the start.
Very atmospheric!  It got so I was finding them by sight, though.  I'm not sure if that was a bug, but there didn't seem to be any sound coming from some of them.

Enjoyed this one a lot. I was very confused at first because I had configured my controls but didn't realize I could use the mouse to look around.

This game is all atmosphere, and well executed. It wasn't hard to find the radios and it was a neat to hear the soundscape (a major part of the atmosphere) change as I did. I wish there had been an "inverted" mouselook; that was actually the biggest challenge for me. :)
Very atmospheric. I wish it had a bit more challenge to it, but it was still fun to search for the radios based on sound. Discovering the first one was a good moment.

Great atmosphere...

jeje, you are not going to do an rpg ever!!!

Is amazing that you managed to do something in only one day. Congratulations.
Oh wow. I like this; very original. I'm impressed how atmospheric it is for having such simple graphics. It comes off as unfinished, but I certainly like where you were going with it.

OOH. This fancy.
I liked it very much.
Managed to finish this. It is a fun game and I love the atmosphere. Reminded me of some weird old twilight zone or outer limits episode.

Love the atmosphere, the non textured low poly area feels quite alien. But why oh why did you put jump on space and not on the mouse. Very unconvenient if you're walking with the cursor keys.
And I didn't find the last radio :(

This was kind of cool.
I think I relied on audio much less than was intended; I foudn most of them by wandering in a methodical way around each interesting looking island.
And then my screen faded to black. Is this a game over screen? It's kind of like the underwater thing  except jumping doesn't make it go away.

Great atmosphere. Excellent use of audio. Sometimes and I had to close my eyes to focus on the sound to found all radios. I think it could be better if you die if you stay too long in the water. Great game. Congratulations.
It's a shame that you didn't have time to properly polish this out! The radio system was very interesting, and I would've loved to see some underwater scenes or something.
Hehe,..yes, really nice! Acually after playing the game the dogs of the neighbor hood came to my house after hearing this "dog-whistle" :D! Nice job...
Adored the atmosphere.  It's a bit of the shame the gameplay wasn't a great deal more than "find the objects" but at least you did something cool with it.  I loved the sea radio.

Amazing.
Reminds me of Myst and the new teaser thing they added to Portal. Great game, especially for only one day's work.

I don't really see the connection to the theme, except superficially.

description: A game where you dive for stars. Get them all to win.

somehow, buoyancy = -gravity is totally awesome.
really feels good to complete this one too, you get favourable scores from me on this :)
Yeah sorry my previous comment was kinda useless... And I agree, it really is pretty awesome when you complete the game. I love the style of puzzle element this game has.

BOING BOING BOING BOING
STAR

Nice realisation and everything, but I really dont get this one oO

3 hours?! This is great. I haven't won this yet (5 stars left) but I'll come back for it :)

description:
It's here! The stuff of dreams, an entry for the epic Ludum Dare has been made!
The game is a one button game where you hop from island to island. It was fairly rough to make a game in just 48 hours, yeah I'm a newbie, but it was pretty fun too!
Source: http://github.com/treeman/ludumdare17
author: treeman
title: Beebop The Island Hopper
comments: AAaah can get to the last island, but can't coordinate enough to end it : (  Fun though, once I figured it out : )
This game practically had me jumping up and down in frustration(the good kind). :)

Surprisingly compelling game mechanic, but I gave up in frustration on the second last island.  The easier bits could/would work very well if combined with something else though, and it was pretty fun for a while.

Yay, victory! :)
And annoyingly frustrating, when I went back the three last islands again and again. 
Well done!
An odd little timing game. Rather harder than it at first seems.
Fun game! VERY VERY Hard! I wish the victory part was a bit more rewarding, but at least I won! :)
Very nice game. Took me awhile to figure out what it was about. The end was nicely challenging and I managed to finish it.

An interesting entry! I actually found it pretty fun to track the patterns. I found myself singing little songs in my head to track the beat of each thing. It would be interesting to try syncing the rhythms to music; you could probably get away with much shorter and rarer green windows that way.
I liked the idea and played to the end. For all the islands I could just "feel" when it was time to move, but the last one I resorted to tapping out a beat.
Simple, but fun mechanic! I couldn't quite get that last one...
