Great strategy game! Here's what I liked the most:
- I could pick up and play fairly easily; tooltips worked great for learning how to play.
- The basic premise where everything is a structure (including ships, etc.) sits great with me and is a smart simplification for the competition.
- Strategy is pretty great for a 48 hour compo.
- Writing is also great, I really understood what was going on.

The only thing I had trouble with is is balance:
- The monsters! They seem to get really powerful really fast, not leaving me much chance to amass enough for leaving the island.
- Strategy wise, it's not clear to me that food/wood ever matter very much; this might be something I'm missing out on?
- It's not totally obvious the relationship between metal+magic=power, other than it's not really linear.

Basically in order to have a hope of beating the monsters I had to build as many cities on mountains as I could manage, and as many forges as I could without overdepleting my metal supply. Then just work for the rest of the turn.

Here is a suggestion, (surely the wrong one but it might give you some ideas) for balancing the game:

- Make it so the monsters ramp up a bit slower
- The game could tell you what kind of monster is coming up
- The monsters require some number each of food, wood, metal, magic to defeat; this way you are encouraged to always increase.
- Maybe the battle could happen more on a sliding scale, where you see the effects of your resources; different types of monsters may have different effect on the resources so that you get a feel for what you need to have
- The worse you do in battle, the more magic you lose

This would let you:
- Know what effect your resources had on each monster type.
- Be encouraged to learn what each monster is like ("oh no, it's a fire gryphon, better stockpile wood this turn...")
- Make it so that if you manage your resources properly, you can save up your magic thereby giving you a better chance to escape.

Anyhow this is way too much information! Great job, I had fun with this game.

comments: This is one of those games that is so terrible that it's great. I had a nice laugh at that absurdness of it all.
Nice job. The guitar and hand drawn graphics was cool.
Heh, I liked the flashdark idea.

I loled a few times, clicked away the messages a few times before i had a chance to read them. Also did'nt see/read the hint on the beach note until the third try or so. Graphics are spot on, great realism.
Nice job!  I especially liked the early glimpse of the vampire.  I got stuck a couple of times though, randomly clicking everywhere and hoping to find something.
This game wins everything. The metroid reference especially pleases. My girlfriend and I both laughed, in every room.

description:
I can't believe I managed to finished something I had basically no gameplay until 7 hours before the end. I lost a lot of time not knowing what I wanted to do and trying physics stuff that didn't work.
EDIT: I've fixed a little bug with turtles getting out of sync that would have most likely prevented people from finishing the game.
INSTRUCTIONS: Since I didn't include any help with my game (sorry), the game is played with WASD keys to move, mouse to look around and SPACE to jump.
UPDATE: Mac version now available (Untested). Source code (Unity Project) also available.
author: Codexus
title: Tropical Islands of Doom
comments:
I was able to run this on 'fantastic' settings at 1080 without a single hiccup. Apart from some popup issues and the clipping, it's quite beautiful.

My biggest gripe is that the turtles just slide out from under you... and the penguin drowns. lol

Very nice graphics - some good textures/models/lighting there, certainly one of the prettiest LD entries around.

Let down a little by the camera controls/camera clipping through things (I tried playing it on a laptop touchpad, though)

I must check out Unity some time soon :)

Aargh inverted vertical camera control! 

Aside from that, though, it looks pretty damn good! Nice looking models and crisp textures. I would have liked some sort of animation for the player character - it always looks so wrong just sliding a stiff model around (at least when it's an organic character like this).

Game is beautiful!  This is some place I'd like to vacation, if not for the frictionless turtles and inverted camera.  

Sounds and music fit the game pretty well.  

Mechanic wasn't too interesting, but exploring the environment made it worthwhile.
Controls are a little finnicky, but the game was otherwise nice. Nice environment.
The Camera controls get me the most in this game. Very good graphics and very nice that you got a 3d Unity project finished in 48 hr. I liked being a penguin.
The camera controls are brutal but otherwise a good entry.
Very nice! The turtles look like giant bloated ticks. lol!

Fantastic graphics! It's unbelievable that you did this in just a weekend. Wonderfull.

But seriously the inverted y axis camera control freaked me out.

A very pretty game. The penguin and the turtles look unnaturally shiny though. The penguin looks like it's made of rubber and the turtles look like they're polished marble or something. Regardless, the gameplay is pretty basic. The level design was pretty good though; I only missed one treasure chest on my first run through, even though technically the world is completely open for me to go anywhere.

Excellent work getting this thing together! As others have mentioned, the inverted Y axis is a big negative mark for me. Also, staying on the turtles is extremely difficult.

I really liked the exploration aspect.

Very pretty! I liked the music too.

I must admit, it is difficult to tell how much of this is your hard work, and how much of it is just Unity. Especially since you've admitted to being lazy, in your timelapse post. ;)

Not to worry, I've given you the benefit of the doubt. :)

Alas it would run quite jerky even on fastest setting. I however found 4 chests before giving up on the triple barrel jump.
Nice idea, exploring is fun, the camera control is most annoying though.

Amazing use of tools. I know you've talked about it some, but could you write a more in-depth article talking about your use of tools in the game.

In particular, I'd like to know how you did the islands and the textures for the islands.

How you did the turtle textures, barrels textures and the flags and the waving of the flag, and the grass and the wood textures.

How you did the bird and turtle models, and other models.

How you did the shadows, amazing water and reflections, etc.

Please more details. I like to work smarter, not harder too.

Thanks!~
Really great use of Unity, a very polished and complete feeling game. Had problems with the camera but in general enjoyed playing.
Wow, an LD48 that makes my graphics card fan actually spin up. =p Camera controls, yada yada. Had fun with it though.

The graphics are quite nice looking, especially the sky. Music isn't bad either. However, no matter what settings I try using, on multiple computers, I find myself unable to keep the camera under control - the slightest twitch of the mouse and I'm looking at either the sky or the ground; it essentially became impossible to play. Pity, it looks like it could have been fun.
Attractive, good work on the content.  Did suffer a bit from the seemingly common unity "find x things" effect, but the inclusion of some platforming elements raised the gameplay a bit.
The best graphics in a LD ever! :P (at 10 FPS, thoug LOL)

description:
Catalog the animals and learn to evolve.
FEATURING
*Total historical accuracy: Mystery protagonist!
*Catalog seven LEGENDARY animals
*Evolving! Total scientific accuracy.
*Jumping!
*Not enemies and other stuff that I didn't have time to add!

author: JMNielly
title: The Naturalist
comments:
I must say that I really liked this game!
The evolution mechanic is just brilliant.
I would have liked a bigger level/more levels though and maybe the ability to win :P

Pretty cool, though I would have saved this idea for when Evolution was the theme ;)

All in all, a pretty fun platformer with an interesting mechanic. I did find the audio a little lacking though.

The only bad thing about this game is that there's not more of it and you never got to explore the awesome effects of this system. It really felt like the original Boy and his Blob but unfortunately didn't have the resulting interactions in place. I'd definitely like to see this one continued though as mixing Kirby style role-pickups with ABAHB style puzzle interactions would be awesome.

So after the mole, that is it?

In any case great idea and very polished, just could use more content.

For the 1 minute i was playing the entirety of this game, i thought it was ingenious, Please continue developing this game. With more content this could be a really brilliant game.
One thing i'd say thought if you do develop it more is to not let the player get lots of upgrades in the first 30 seconds. ;)

The whole concept is very cool, remembered me of the boy and his blob and E.V.O.
Too bad it was not complete, that would make an awesome platforming game!
Cool concept, you should totally keep working on this!

Cool concept, nice graphics. Physics were a bit off I think. And the lack of proper ending is a bit frustrating.
As they say, try to make it more, it'd be great!

Huh. Cool. Not really theme appropriate, at all, but cool.
The Good - Evolution mechanic was awesome. Im a little unclear on what the tuxedo and the turtle shell did, and it would have been neat to have more evolutions. It DID make for a neat potential metroidvania if you ever finish it tho.
The Bad - Well... this wasnt much of a game. It also didnt have much to do with islands (I mean, I guess it was on an island.
The Ugly - almost total lack of audio. The little bit of audio there was, was clearly made with a single click in sfxr. 
All in all, kinda neat. Ima look at your source, despite the fact that I dont hate myself, mostly because I want to see what you did for the player evolving graphics. I have a theory you just made him in multiple parts and loaded different graphics when he evolved, but I want to see if you came up with something better then that.
Liked the evolution (mutation?) mechanic. Very polished for what it is.
Really nice concept. I hope you take some time to expand on this :)
The idea is grand! Keep developing this game, add lots more to evolve, but don't overwhelm the player at once.

I guess you were rooting for "Evolution" to win the theme poll? :-)
Too bad the game doesn't have an end, or much anything to do after you get the mole claw. I was hoping something would let me swim to another island, but I guess it wasn't in the stars. I hope you continue working on it. I never found any use for the turtle shell or the tuxedo. Did those actually do something?
Also, I didn't quite understand why Hannibal Lecter is cataloging animals. ;-)

This has some potential, but it's pretty short and a couple of the abilities... didn't really help. I thought there was a puzzle that you had to avoid the penguins after grabbing the turtle shell, so you could go swim. More of that kind of thing would be cool. Still, cool idea, maybe develop this one some more.
Ah ha! So _that's_ how evolution works.
This was really good, the mechanic was really nice. You could definitely "evolve" this into a much more substantial game, making the various evolutions part of puzzles.
Haha! This is a great idea and the graphics are hilarious. I wish that you had gotten to the game part. :) Evolved tuxedo, hehe.

Really liked this game! Great use of the theme, funny and fun.
Couldn't finish it, I'm afraid, but it was fun while it lasted...
This is amazing. It's like E.V.O. on LSD. Please expand it, it'd be awesome.

description:
What can be more tragic than the failure of a personal quest for damnation? That's a question Simulacrum, and the whispering memories of a broken man seek to answer. But when is there an answer? There is no truth and no answers in our world. And yet we ask: Will Walter succeed? Will he be able to leave the Island before the nightfall?
There is only one way to find out...
Controls:
Arrow Keys - Move/Shoot
Up, Z, Space - Jump
F4 - Full Screen
J - Mute Sound
You can walljump, and you must walljump.
The game saves automatically at the beginning of every level.
Simulacrum was made using Game Maker 8.
author: Comtemno
title: Simulacrum
comments:
I fell out of one of the screens - going up the gap at hte start, then falling off.  And I couldn't restart, and I don't want to play through what I did again right now (but I might later on).

Once I got used to the controls, it felt pretty good to hop around.

Ha! I found that same hole that increpare did. I thought it was going to lead to a secret area -- turns out it wasn't planned.

Anywho, I thought the game was overly heavy on dialog with little action (even leading to the dialog).
Lots of Dialog but I like how it doesn't force you to stop and listen. Also you can get stuck on the gold that is supposed to disappear. Not sure how I did that but I did.

kay.... I seem to have come up with a quick system of reviewing things, inspired by spaghetti westerns.
The good - The soundtrack was rather nice, super minimalist, but it worked really well with the game. The Graphics where kind of the same way. Minimalist, and not astounding, but they worked (almost) perfectly.
The Bad - Controls where almost to responsive. I had to re do so many jumps just because I moved ever so slightly to fast, or wall jumped slightly to high or low. It got kinda aggravating.
The Ugly - so umm... your trails where backwards. Why?

All in all, it was pretty good, although slightly heavy handed. I couldnt decide if I liked the narration, or hated it, honestly. Good message to the game overall, but the heavy handed presentation detracted from it. I also thought you where going for the copout that he was dead and the island was purgatory, so Im glad you shied away from that option (as it would have basically been the final straw and tipped me into hating the dialogue.)
The movement was a bit too quick for my reflexes. Definitely a solid engine otherwise!

I think the game was too fast. I don't mean story-wise, that went by too quickly. Maybe I just don't play enough platform games, but the only way I succeeded in the jumps was repetition. If the movement had been much slower, it would be that much more playable.

I'm not sure I got the whole storyline, because the game moved too fast. Because of the fast character movement, I think I missed a few dialog boxes. With a slower character, I think the game could be much better in this respect.

Polished entry. Plays fine, if a tad too fast. The wall jump is good to control.
The end is somewhat abrupt.
I liked the walljumping but as others have said, it was a bit too fast. Still a good game.

"Contemners impose judgment to divide their prey from the pack." Seems somewhat appropriate.

An interesting game, though the controls are entirely hyperactive. Slowing movement down would have helped a lot. Loading saved games was a bit buggy as well. Other than that, quite a lot of fun to play.

Also, I agree with some of the other reviewers that the story was heavy-handed, but I disagree that that's a bad thing. Sometimes, for some games, that's exactly what you need, and this is one of those games.
WOW.  Beautiful.  Only played through level 3 though, got stuck in a wall, will continue later though!

description:
Well, it's done! Not only that, but I did it without a single other blog post or going in the IRC (I smell a 5/5 on community). This game is also incomplete in a lot of ways, and seems to be buggy, but I didn't have time to fix it! Probably because I spent most of my time slacking off as I didn't really like the theme that much. Anyways, hope you enjoy somewhat idling while waiting to get more attack in the game!
Instructions:
*The land you own is blue. You can click on it to select it, and anything you can attack will turn red.
*When you attack something, you'll attack it by ((your attack power - 1) divided by 2).
*You will be able to see more of the island as you take over more ground
*Normal land will get + 1 every 15 seconds, while big land will get + 2.
Resources aren't yet finished, and even if they were, you wouldn't be able to do anything with them. You also can't transfer troops from land to land, so this probably makes the game impossible in this state! Anyways, that pretty much covers it. Have fun!
Note: The game is SUPER SIZE. Hope this doesn't affect your gameplay, but it probably will!
author: Blackduck
title: Risky Island
comments:
Could be a nice strategy game, but as it is there just isn't any real gameplay.
I won the land next to mine but somehow was not able to claim another one.

Yeah, I'm really missing the troop transfer...  I shouldn't be attacking my own land!  If you don't like the theme, that just means you took it too literally :)
There are a few game-killing bugs, too.  I got one enemy land stuck at 5 and another that replenished using my troops.
I agree with the previous commentors. The idea is good, but the game would need more polishing and an AI opponent or something.
I had to jump through hoops to get the .swf file to play by itself. Sorry you didn't like the theme.

description:
- Gather as much Booty as possible over 3 voyages!
- Raid ships and hunt for hidden treasure!
(Full instructions on the web site.)
--------------
Gameplay
It's a little turn-based game that plays a bit like Minesweeper and forces you to make trade-offs to maximize your score.
I hope you like it!
--------------
Known Issues:
Sometimes the random placement of objects is too clustered together.
--------------
Tools Used:
Photoshop for graphics.
FL Studio for audio/music.
Code in Haxic - a BASIC dialect for ActionScript, compiled by HaXe.

You can find it here:
http://haxic.wordpress.com/
author: frosty
title: Pee Wee Pirates
comments: Nice to see so much fun from a tiny game, great tunes as well!

Really good game. You followed the theme good, it was really fun and the tune fit perfectly. 

The only thing was the slightly iffy goal, your task is to score as high as you can but somewhere it felt like it didn't matter as you had three runs and then it's over no matter what you do. An idea for the future is to make the levels harder and make it so that you can only go to the next if you enough bounty.

My favorite game so far!
Arr, 4200 score! Fun little game with a catchy, piratey tune.
A high booty table would be nice :)
I quite enjoyed this. :) Fun gameplay and perfect audio. Great stuff!
Very fun, nice music. Addicting gameplay.
5900! fun little game. I like the mix of being able to go on-foot to find booty. YAR!

I really liked this one!  My favorite part being that your moves are dictated by how much rum you have, of course...

I think the goal of just trying to get as much booty as possible in 3 short voyages could improved upon; something to make the game last longer!  Definitely had fun anyway, though.

Great game! Lots of fun trying to plan ahead to make sure you'll have enough rum to get booty and to the next town. :)

I found the input/movement a little slow, but I guess it's a ship. Can't expect them to go super fast, eh? :)
Pretty cool. Treasure seemed hard to find. Maybe some indication of "there is treasure within 5 tiles of you but you don't know where it is"?

Nice game :)
Tough rum limit, but I managed to explore the full map on voyage one.
Solid fun!
Simple, but very fun to play! If only controlling the ship was a bit more fluid!
Your computer on a cage rack is AWESOME. Your game is also AWESOME. Keep working on it! I wanna see this expanded!

a bit bare-bones, but fun as long as it lasted.

description:
Tools:
- code: FlashDevelop (Flash ActionScript 3)
- sound: sfxr + musagi
- graphics: Inkscape + Gimp
Libraries:
- Flixel v1.25
- TweenLite v6.21
This is a story of a non-specified insignificant stone god, who dwells in distant dark waters, near a group of islands.
Once in a while he climbs out of his cozy abyss to look upon the world and all the new islands and things,
that came to existence since his last visit. He likes to mangle and twist destinies.
I had a lot of fun creating various creatures and their interaction rules, I wish I had just one more day to add more content.
GOAL:
Get 15 achievements, have fun.
Move islands over the map, so that the living creatures could traverse between them.
When you're done, enter the abyss to finish the level.
In each of 7 levels, new islands appear, bearing new items and creatures.
Creatures interact with items and each other according to given rules. Accomplishing some of the interactions will get you an achievement.
Minimap (you're white, abyss is red) and stone plaques (with tips) may help you.
CONTROLS:
CURSOR KEYS - movement
X - jump
author: jarnik
title: Islands of the Stone God
comments: Good game! i really like the idea of the different interactions between different objects!
That was pretty awesome! I played it twice to see what all I could do, was great! Loved the abstract pixel graphics and the low rumble of the music was nice and wasn't too over-bearing.

Very cool stuff, spent quite some time playing this one. Love the art. Only downside is the quite repetitive music, there is loads of room for atmosphere to fulfill in such a game. Otherwise, however, top-notch!
Interesting idea. There were some technical flaws here and there (scrolling), but nothing too bad. I couldn't totally figure out what I was supposed to do in the later levels, though.
Very very awesome, a bit too freeform in that it wasn't obvious how stuff would interact at first, but incredibly polished end product and lovely art and sound design.
I love this kind of sandbox achievement finder game, great work!
I quite enjoyed that - mainly the starting sections, though after a while I found it seemed to loose some pace.
I guess it could use a little bit more in the way of directions, not very clear. Otherwise, interesting idea.
I was confused yet entertained. I dug the sounds.
Liked the concept though it was kind of hard to know what to do without the list of achievements easily available.
I sort of figured out that some stuff would interact, but I didn't feel like I had much control. I never found reason to jump.

Original and interesting idea. I loved the graphic style. First time I wasnt sure what to do, but second time I play (and read the description) was fun. I think it has a lot of potential. Congratulations.

Neat concept, loved the interaction stuff. Alas with 48 hours there's only so much you could do.
Plus for the Star Trek combination ;)
I felt it a bit slow, however I like the concept and I think you did a great job. It remind me somehow to civilization.

Great concept and fantastic use of the theme.

It could have been clearer when you triggered a combination or not. But still it worked great.

Excellent job and the look of the game was a perfect fit. Especially nice touch making the "god" a giant floating monolith thing..
Really great, highly original, atmospheric and fairly fun.  Though I didn't feel especially compelled to replay, there's a grain of brilliance here.  An impressive achievement in the timescale.

description:
An intriguing mix of card game and tower defense game.
Made in C# with XNA 3.1 ( so you'll need that version to play. Link in readme).
I'm really quite please with the game. It's quite fun, and even though the easiest level is a tad too hard (a total noob should be able to win it the first time preferrably), and the Very Hard one might very well be impossible, there's a nice range of difficulty levels depending on what you're after.
There's certainly more that could be done with this game but I'm happy with the result given the small amount of time I had for it. :)
Again, if it crashes for you, just get the XNA 3.1 redist:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=53867a2a-e249-4560-8011-98eb3e799ef2&displaylang=en
During playtesting it was interesting to notice how, before I put up the "seriously, do this" text in the menu, no-one looked at the help screen. You really have to force players to do these kinds of things.
Oh and yes, there's a bug which has to do with the money: It seems to be off by one every now and then. Quite annoying, and I knew about it before submission, but I didn't think it'd be that frequent. And I was tired ;)
author: Srekel
title: Islands At War
comments:
Pretty entertaining

Won't start second turn though after you win a round
Great idea, love the cards and having to build the bridges. Wish you could upgrade your towers, different types of weapons. Sounds would have been nice..

Crashed without XNA installed, bummer. :(

Game makes sense and works right. Being quick seems more important than strategy. Bridges being unbreakable and the distance along the graph being irrelevant means there's not much subtlety with them. One card tower is plenty to get more cards than you need; the problem is that you're at the whim of the dice with those.

Once, it wouldn't accept my clicks on the third play.

Hard mode is very hard! A lot of it is the luck of your first few cards. I did want to keep playing it. :)
It crashed upon opening the file. :(

Well, that's pretty neat, but a bit too luck based at least on the hardest difficulty. I'm also still confused as to how the finances work. In the screenshot right there, how much does a gold tower actually cost? It's not free because you can't build it without any money. Is this just a bug?
I think the towers lack feedback in general. It's kinda hard to keep track of how much damage you're dealing to the ships or the HQ. Some elements of this reminded me of Plants VS Zombies. If you decide to develop this further, I'd look at PvZ for some pointers.
I like the idea of the game, it is a good mixing of genres.
I REALLY like this. Sounds and more of a challenge / more levels would make it pretty amazing. KEEP GOING!!!

author: moltanem2000
title: Island World
comments: It would be cool to have a speed adjuster that would allow me to speed up night and day even faster. asides for that I can't think of anything else to add. Well made game fun to be able to collect power-ups and build your own world.
Fun game, i never understood how the underlying system for when you got what tool/weapon tought. The day/night cycle could be a bit shorter aswell. Really liked the intro!

Very interesting idea but somehow it was very hard for me to get into it. I didn't understand when I earned a new tool (do you need to gather different tiles?)

Also, I have no idea how to fight back actually. I didn't get the sword and don't know what to collect for that. A bit more details in the intro would've helped a lot.

A clever little game with cute graphics and an amusing intro. Unfortunately, whenever nighttime rolled around and the screen got dark, performance for me dropped precipitously and the CPU spiked, which basically meant that when night approached I had to find a safe spot to stand and not move at all until morning. Which somewhat diminished my enjoyment, but overall it was still a good game. Rather difficult, but eventually you get the hang of it.

I liked collecting different materials and making things. 

When I got to a pirate lair, I killed everyone and nothing happened - I didn't know what to do from there. 

Also, when I got the sword I didn't know how to use it. I assumed I had to click on the pirates. It was only later that I noticed the tooltip that said to use shift.

Apart from that, I thought this was great. Especially the little lantern.
It was hard for me to figure out how to play at first. A tutorial would be great.

This is super polished, and nobody ever has a big intro cutscene!  I would say that really thoroughly explained the game, but once I played I had NO clue what was going on.  I don't understand the other peoples' comments because they seemed to understand an awful lot more of it than I did.  I read about shift, so I did get to sword some pirates, but other than that, all I could figure out how to do was vaporize as much as possible to obtain powerups (seemingly at random?  I dunno), with which to vaporize more.  Can the pirates ever be stopped?  More seemed to come all the time, and night was extremely hard to deal with.  Usually I just had to sit and wait because I couldn't see a thing where I happened to be when it switched.

But it's weird, because it's obviously quite cool and well-polished.  I just can't figure out what the rules are.

description:
Voyage for the Queen requires Silverlight 3. It may work with Moonlight on Linux but is untested as of yet.
Important: If you are playing the original version and the queen asks you to get her 5000 gold coins reload. You will never finish!
The premise is that you are a ship captain that the Queen tasks to get a certain number of items (It is random). You must sail between the islands to obtain the requested number of items to win the game. Pirates will attempt to steal your cargo so you must also stock cannons and swords to fight them with.
There is a strategy guide posted here: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/04/28/strategy-guide-for-voyage-for-the-queen/
The game was written using Visual Studio and Silverlight. It is using the WriteableBitmapEx library for blitting. Photoshop was used for the graphics.
The bugfix version has the following fixes. The original is also in a link above for the purists:
*Pirates who manage to get through both cannon and sword defenses will now steal all your stuff rather than just saying they did.
*The queen will now not select coins or cannons for the quest as they were problematic.
*Pirates can no longer show up with negative number of swords and cannons.
*Removed exploit where player could get out of a pirate battle by hitting the X on the window.

The Good - umm... not that many people made trading games? Everything worked fine. The pictures of people where kinda cute.
The bad - clunky controls, boring as hell to play.
The Ugly - spritework. Lack of audio. Total lack of innovation.

It should be noted that Im not really that into trading games, so this review may be unnecessarily brutal. I also got frustrated by silverlight crashing my computer on install, but thats not really your fault (although it definitely made me a little aggravated by the time I started playing this.)

I stopped playing when pirates hit my ship. First I was happy because they didn't took my bananas, which I was gathering, but then I went to resupply at the Queen's castle and lost all my bananas. I mean, the game did warn me, but I figured since the pirates didn't take the bananas, the Queen's resupply wouldn't either. I wish I could had just dropped off the bananas I had and continued getting the rest.
I think the game also needs a compass or a map to help you find the Queen again. I managed to find her, but I wasn't sure I was going the right way until I did.
Basically though, fun basic trading game.

I'm giving you a bit of points on innovation and humor, but the connection to the theme is pretty vague and you obviously didn't put a lot of effort into this.

description:
SkyLands is about islands in the sky. You play as Vapor the Airboarder who is trying to collect all the lightning bolts to get the Wind Machines back up and going so everyone can once again airboard from island to island.
Game has 2 levels.
Controls:
up arrow moves up
down arrow moves down
left arrow moves left
right arrow moves right
up and down arrows to navigate through menus
enter or space to choose options in the menu
Ctrl will turn off/on sound
Shift will turn off/on full screen
author: Diet Chugg
title: SkyLands
comments:
Great music and variety!

Graphics were cute, could have used sound effects. The start-over gameplay is a bit frustrating.
Nice music, but the graphics seemed kind of crappy. Other than that, I did enjoy the idea of "Just move around find the lightning bolts". It was pretty calming

Great fun! The simplest ideas are sometimes the best.

Never managed to beat the second level though, these rotating ones are nasty. Adn sometimes the collision detection is a bit severe.

But the great music made me want to finish the game!
Nice. Simple idea, and the second level is actually harder than one might think.

Awesome music. But I've got to agree with others' critiques: the restarting levels deterred me from finishing the game.

If you don't mind me doing so, Diet Chugg, I rehosted your game here:
http://galacticgaming.net/hosting/ludum/SkyLands.exe
Excellent audio. Simple and fun gameplay. Restarting after dying impeded me to finish the game.

Not bad. I played through to the "end" (hint: you can see the "end" by pressing the cheat-key 'esc' at any time :)) and it was challenging even given the simple goal. The biggest hazard was getting stuck on a wall, because if that happens and there isn't a whirlwind coming, you have to use the cheat key to start over from the first level. Nice, weird music.
I really like this. =)  Great music.  Neat back story.  The graphics are rough but fun.  I especially like the main character hover dude.  Overall good work for a 48h entry.
I liked dodging the stale bugles and picking up the fruit snacks with my GOLDEN FLEECED SAMUEL ADAMS ON A HOVERBOARD.

description:
Barely playable time trial racing game. Use up to accelerate, left and right to turn, crash three times and you're out (but you can buy extra lives and upgrades when you reach an island, for a time penalty), if you complete the three tracks then the game will quit on you because I didn't get round to coding an end screen but you can see your final time by checking the itr.log file. The game is intentionally set to use the same courses and available upgrades every time for now so that you can compare times.
Uploaded another screenshot to prove the pit islands between the courses actually exist, un-islandy as they are. :)
author: shockedfrog
title: Island Tour Racing
comments:
Where are the islands? 
lol

I die too fast. I can never get past the first 2 turns.
Beat it. There isn't much here, and the game's very easy, but I guess you could create something fun onto this base. :)

Your total time was 85.786003. Congrats!

Damn, you should force the player to a short pause after dying. Right now if I die once I keep up pressed and immediately drive into the borders again.

Some fine tuning on the controls, nifty graphics and you could make this a great little game!

description:
Story: You were a robot on a ship, you crash landed with your friends! (only one actually).  You have to rescue them.  Once you find a GPS (minimap) you can see their location and find them better.  Beware of the native wood chucks and snakes that spit!
The different versions are different resolutions.
You will need the .Net Framework 3.5
You will need the XNA Runtime 3.1
I was way too ambitious on the map size, 1024x1024 tiles, only playable part is about a quarter of that.  There are are lots of items scattered throughout the world to play with.  I didn't get nearly as far as I wanted to.  The music is awful, I know, the sound effects are pretty bad too.  Alas, it was my first time.
Different Windows downloads are different resolutions, only difference between them.  Should have made that more clear, sorry.
Basic controls: WASD / Arrow keys
Jump: space bar / 0 on number pad
Attack: F / left control / 1 on number pad
Change Weapons: 1, 2, 3
Use Acid: Enter
Save: F8
Load: F9
Cheat Mode / edit mode: F1
Known issues:
Sometimes jump doesn't register correctly.
Sometimes the slash screen displays for a couple of seconds before the Game Over or You Win screens.
author: billknye
title: Island Robotica
comments: As you say, a very ambitious project! It looks pretty good right now, but it needs more work. I would humbly suggest concentrating on a much smaller subset of features instead of spreading yourself thin.

That's a game that I'd love to see fleshed out and polished up.
Very ambitious, probably too ambitious for 48 hours. I only found a gun beside the target beacon. I once pressed F1 and after that my robot was slow again (I had gotten an extra motor before).
Quite well done!

Conceptually good, but has some issues. It seemed like the map was littered with invisible walls. It seemed I could never fit into single tile spaces, even though the car/robot seems to be that size. I also found brown areas that looked like bridges but that I could not drive on, which was strange. By that time though, I could jump high enough that I could drive a bit into the water and jump across. That I also found weird. That I couldn't drive on some areas that looked drivable, but could drive a little way into the water. The only gun I found was the zapper, which was a bit annoying to use since I could not move while using it. It's like it was a temporary landmine or something like that. One final thing was that I had little clue as to where I need to go, except the little star on the map, but then that was my main goal. I had very little clue on my immediate minor goals. I was also a bit confused at first because I couldn't jump but if I pressed space it would still make a sound and I would lose energy.
Sorry about all the complaints. The good news is that those are not too difficult to improve upon. :-)
invisible walls is not fun how they were used. Preinstalling stuff was not fun. killing snakes and lizards was fun however. Good start to the game. Liked collecting powerups.

description:
Not quite how I wanted it to turn out, but it's sort of playable...
You start by controlling one tank, on one island. Each turn, you can choose to shoot with a tank, colonize another island, or create a new tank. New tanks can only be placed on colonized islands.
The enemy has the same goal. When either you or the computer runs out of tanks, the game is over.
Press space-bar to switch between the 3 turn types (new tank, colonize, shoot). Press tab to cycle through your tanks. WASD or arrow-keys to spin the planet. The text in the game should contain most of the instructions needed.
The source is a horrible mess of spaghetti code that wouldn't happen anywhere other than in a 48-hr game competition ;).
Languages/libraries used:
C++
LibNoise
Havok
Bass
Apps used:
Photoshop
3DS Max
Reason (for music)
SFXR (for sounds)
Hope you enjoy it!
author: mattdev
title: Island Planet!
comments: Doesn't works on my netbook. So bad cause it looked awesome.
Lots of fun! though a little on the easy side. good job!
Great concept and great game, but at some point it just stuck on opponent's turn...
Great concept, but your AI falls very short after a few rounds.

Nice. I dig spherical worlds since Populous the Beginning.

There's some z buffering artifacts on my laptop, but nothing game breaking. Winning is quite easy so far, maybe add some more challenges?

I like the choices of turn types! It keeps things fresh and moving along instead of going through stages every time it's your turn. Also, there is an element of choice.

As mentioned, it is too bad that the AI is so simple. But great graphic concept, and it's pretty fun!
Dude,...I just like it! It whole game feels just right. Graphics perfect, clear gameplay without any problems to understand what to do....very good job
Doesn't run on my laptop so I cannot rate it... Game looked fun though.

My mouse is hidden in game which makes clicking on stuff tricky.
Interesting concept though. The turn choices are a nice touch.
IA doesn't place new tanks so i won in a few rounds.
I found it hard to figure out how to attack! But the game seemed very cool.

description:
I guess I'm done. Pretty happy with it. I could probably keep going a little longer but I stop when I stop enjoying working, which is now, dig?
Arrows move
Space to jump
Anything else to throw shovels
Find clues to figure out where to jump
Get treasure.
Be awesome.
author: Xion
title: Island Jumper
comments: Really cool, though the scanlines raped my eyesight a little. The jump mechanic was a bit longwinded, but i enjoyed wandering around a lot.

I really like the concept, but the jumping felt too cumbersome(I think it would work if you knew the arc beforehand and the gameplay was about fuel management instead), and nullness errors ended the game prematurely.
Love the art style. The jumping takes some getting used to, but it was fun.
It's too hard for me and I keep walking into the water.

What a funny idea to jump to other parts. Although the jumping mechanic is a bit tedious in the long run.

Bailed with a script error when I took a huge jump unto the right end of the map.

This was WAY fun. Hard as crap, but waaaaay fun.

Could've used some bassy, thumpin' music, though.

I got this...
___________________________________________
ERROR in
action number 1
of  Step Event
for object sys_messages:

Error in code at line 11:
   x = ob_player.x
                 ^
at position 16: Unknown variable x

Not really liking the scanlines nor the fact that I have to "end task" in order to quit the game early. I do like the mechanic, though that's a lot of variables to play with. Good job overall.

Oh, I crashed with errors too by jumping to the south with full incline and a lot of power from the circle thingy to the south-west of where you start.
This was rather nice. Found it a little tricky, but definitely something that could be evolved into a longer game with a more gradual learning curve.

description:
This is my TD game.
If you DL'd it in the torrent then you should redownload this one, as the torrent one most likely has an unfixed bug!
Hopefully it is bug free and actually possible to win!
@JPLUR: I am unable to have the glitch happen on my machine - what wave is it on and what happens when it reaches the castle?
CONTROLS:
Mouse - Does almost everything
Escape - save and quit to menu
Home - hit this in game if you are getting strange pictures in the background - otherwise don't press it.
BUILDINGS:
Land - 1 Tile land
Small Volcano - Creates a small island
Volcano - Creates a large volcano - you can build stuff onto this volcano
Power - power source
Lava Power - Mega power source from Volcano
Lines - Power lines which carry power
Factory - Gets you a small amount of money when given power
Bank - Gives you "interest" on your money
Gun - Basic weapon
Homing Gun - Very accurate but weaker
Laser - 100% accurate, very strong, but uses lots of power
Taser - A short-range laser that slows enemies
Heater - Damages many enemies in a small radius
Lava Gun - Draws power and lava from a volcano to create a super efficient mega-gun
Bugfixes:
Laser display bug
Graphical Display bug
Bank Bug
#2 Bank bug
Clicking bug
Typos
author: pubby8
title: Island Guns
comments:
Bug, laser towers throw me tons of error messages.

Fun game, by the way.

Oh, and what do factories and banks do?
I like the "power" mechanic, but I've got some pretty nasty graphics corruption when running it on WinXP. I can send you a screenshot if you need.

After inspection it looks like the Graphics buffer on my card wasnt cleared when your game draws and.. isnt cleared.. this is drawing graphics from the previous game i played. and it's constant. Edit: That fixed it.. Nice game. very interesting how you can customize it with new land :)

As a game, it's one of the best on this edition of LD.
I love TDs, and this one was really well built. The concept of a factory and a bank were really creative!

My only complaint is the music, which was getting on my nerves after some wave, which led me to stop playing.

Other than that, awesome game, keep on improving it!
Very addictive. I like the volcano motif. Something is causing me to lose all my money though. I suspect there might be a bug in the banks. It started happening after I built 2.

Very nice tower defense. A lot more variation in towers than in my LD island towers. Very nicely done for a 48h project. I think this is currently the best game I've played in here.

The fighting part could be a bit faster though or allow construction during the fight. Maybe have an option that allows for speed changes or something like that.

Also the game isn't very challenging at the end. I generally like TD games to be extremely challenging towards the end.

As a tower defense fan I've played probably over a hundred different tower defenses. This is one of the most creative tower defenses I've played. And with a bit of fine tuning it has the potential to be one of the best ones.

I like this game a lot.  It is fun to play and challenging.  It is a great use of the theme.  Great work.  
PS If would have been nice if the Factory and Bank has some explanation text, and the power system was vague and caused me to get into trouble more than once.
Great mixture of Tower Defense and Sim Something. I like the added power lines, finally a bit more strategic thought needs to be put in.

This game is actually pretty fun, though I'm really bad at tower defense in general and have not once managed to survive long enough to accumulate enough money to buy anything more expensive than the homing gun. Sad, 'cause the volcano stuff looks pretty cool. Nicely on-theme, too.

Good game! The gameplay is pretty tight. I made some bad choices the first few times playing (it's easy to build guns that can hardly ever hit stuff, because they don't lead shots) but eventually I figured out a good strategy, though I never really quite understood the power flow. The music reminds me of Rampart. Very apropos use of theme. Played this for like 45 minutes. One of the best so far.

It's not super innovative and doesn't really make use of the theme in any spectacular way, but it's DAMN FUN. I hate TD games, but this was very enjoyable. Got to wave 26 before having my entire life brought to a screeching halt!
Great tower defence, the power mechanic made it very tricky and you had to be very strategic, great game and concept, a real amazing turn out from LD

description:
You work for God. You're the guy in charge of drifting continents.
Z = Suck
X = Blow
Coded in AS3 with Flixel. 48 hours ago, I was a Flixel virgin; over the weekend we met and got married. Sound and music thanks to the "DrPetter suite."
Enjoy!
author: hamburger
title: Intercontinental Drift
comments: Nice concept, well executed, and pretty amusing.  After the first level or two it gets *very* hard though.  No-touching is brutal with so many islands in play.
Very nice controlling scheme, also verrry hard. Me likes.
Couldn't get past screen 8, but the controls were really original and interesting.  I also liked the text.
Nice idea. As others have mentioned, I found it very difficult!

I'm finding my feelings towards this game.. difficult to get across.
I like the idea, i think the idea is brilliant, i just dont think it was done that well.. Sorry.
I did however find it very amusing.
Great idea, although it does get brutally hard as previously stated. Good game though =)
Meh? Quite hard, and very annoying music. Mostly I felt like randomly pushing stuff around and see what happened.

It was fun for a few rounds, but then it got stupid hard. I think it would had been challenging enough even if you allowed different colors to collide with each other.
The music gets a bit on my nerves.
Points for being original though.

Love the concept and the gradient representation with particles was excellent. Great flavor text.

The music was unbearable (also kind of unsuited for playing god, you know?).

Now that's an idea, goody goody!
The music gets a tad annoying, and boy, is that game rock hard. Still, a very solid entry.

description:
This is a flash game, made with Flixel, so enjoy in your browser of choice!  Instructions are inside when you click on the big "HELP" on the title screen.  That sentence seems extremely unnecessary but there it is.  That sentence too really had no value.  I'll quit now.
Ooh, here's something worth saying!  I got online scores built into it before release, which makes me pretty awesome, so if you log into your Dumb Account at http://hamumu.com/ before playing, it will record your feats of skill.
I kept my journal at http://hamumu.com/journal.php (feel free to check the timestamps if you want to verify what was in the compo time!), so click on over and bear witness.
author: Hamumu
title: Infinite Deadly Islands Of Terror
comments: Interesting stuff right here. Love the visuals and audio. Movement is a bit sludgy at points but overall it's a fun experience to play!
Really sweet game. I did get bored after a while, but I guess that's a natural side-effect from the infinite levels feature!

The graphics are very nice, but the collision detection with the tiles kept tripping me up, because it seems to go by the pirate's shadow rather than his (more noticeable) head.

I really liked the bridges mechanic as a way to change the layout of the map.

I think it's fun.

Also, the camera can't keep up with my leet speed. This happens a lot with Flixel games for some reason.

Nice little game with cute pixelly graphics. It's a bit too random though, it feels like once you have seen the first island you have seen them all, and the luck factor of where the things spawn is important.

Very interesting and professional. Seemed like a real full-fledged rather than a hurried 48 hour one.
The lack of music would be my only complain...
Very enjoyable. All it needs is music, and maybe Z-sorting. I noticed kiwis ended up on my head :P
Love this! Very nice movement system, though the graphics seemed a tad artifacty at times. Cool mechanics though.
Very fun. :) Your entries are always of exceptional quality with lots of substance.

Nice! The graphics are superb. The gameplay is simple but pretty fun; reminds me of Toe Jam 'n Earl. I think the biggest flaw is that some of the randomly generated levels can be impossible. The very first one I got I was stuck right away, and I was wondering like, is this a difficult puzzle game or what? But when I realized it was random I realized that the extra care to generate only solvable levels was lacking. Hard to blame you for 48 hours. :) Cute concept, story, sound, funny, plays smooth. Very good.

Hi-score 16067
Nice graphics and gameplay. Some piratey themed music would have been great.

GREAT LEVEL GENERATION! That makes for NICE theme interpretation. INFINITE ISLANDS!

Oh, and it helps that the game is pretty fun, too.
I think my level 2 was generated in a way that made it impossible to reach the boat :(.
Good, but some problems with the sprites and the movement

Fun. Good use of theme I think. Your island generation algorithm seems to be pretty good. I didn't even realize at first that they were random. Then on my second run I actually ran into unbeatable levels though. You give a little, you take a little.
Could use some music. The bridge tile should probably fill the space. Now it kinda looks like you might fall through gaps between tiles.

Very polished entry, as usual. Does get a bit boring after while as there's not too much diversity.
Still a solid game.

The hopping pirate bit was pretty funny, and it's a decent game mechanic. The x2 multiplier didn't last long enough to be very useful. Was fun until I got to a level where a tree blocked the only way to the ship :( Otherwise, fun game.
Well,...didn't expect anything but that you again rock the LD! Good JOB!

I liked the gameplay, had a very retro arcade feel and the graphics were nicely drawn. I presume your maps were procedural though because they really let the game down. It mostly felt too easy and bit directionless. I think a handful of designed maps of increasing difficulty would have been much better.
Fun times, well done. Ended getting a bit boring a couple islands in but overall this is very polished.

I love the idea of a pirate with a peg body, reminds me of the old PBF comic where there's a pirate surgeon giving someone a peg aorta, and you see someone with a peg head in the background.

Anyway, fun little game, nice graphics, felt like it could use a little bit more variety (not in level layout, which was very well done, I assume procedurally, but in the kinds of things you find in the levels).

description:
You are a lone risk-taking stick-figure going for the thrill ride of a lifetime, jumping from tiny island to tiny island near Iceland in a valiant and death-defying effort to score points and get the high score!
FEATURES:
REAL TIME 2D WATER PHYSICS (Or a distant facsimile at least)
MUSIC (kinda)
VOICE ACTING (lol)
INSTRUCTIONS:
Press Return/Enter to start the game.  Z jumps, left and right move left and right.  Jump at the peak of the waves for the best distance.  Level 5 is when things start to get interesting...
UPDATE: Finished uploading my Time Lapse to YouTube!  Check it out here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9UNHMj1B1P8
UPDATE 2: Forgot to put the tools/libraries used in making this:
Tools:
XCode (Code)
Pixelmator (Graphics Planning)
Korg iElectribe for iPad (Music)
Audacity (Sound Editing)
sfxr for iPhone (Sound Effects)
Libraries:
OpenGL (Graphics)
SDL (Window Creation)
SDL_image (Font System)
SDL_mixer (Sound System)
*SPOILERS*
Eyjafjallajokull ERUPTS!
author: drakfyre
title: ICELAND, OR: How I learned to stop caring and love Eyjafjallajokull
comments: One of the best entries I've seen so far!
So simple, yet so addictive. I really liked this entry, and the water effects, while seemingly decorative, added a great lot of immersion!
The motion of the 'water' looked great, and the overall feel was nice
I really like the gameplay element, its quite unique. I would have like to seen something in the background however...

Huh, I actually really like that.
The Good - Water pseudo-physics where awesome. Tight controls, good music, appropriate sound fx. Death sound was charming.
The Bad - nothing really. Could have used more levels, and maybe an encouragement for speedruns or jumping really high or something, just so it wasnt jump left, okay, wait a second for the water to chill out, jump left again. Whats that your done? Jump right. Lather rinse repeat.
The Ugly - programmer art. It was actually kind of charming tho, so Im not scoring you down for it.
That's quite interesting. My main criticism is that it takes too long to ramp up and change things.

Now that is something. You captured a good game right there. Controls are precise, the effect is interesting.
And the lava blobs at level 5 came quite as a surprise.
Rock solid entry!
I'm liking this one :)  Personally I'd like it if the lava started coming earlier

Great one! Reminded me of some of the gameplay in N+, but very creative use of the theme and a nice smooth implementation. It gets old faster than it gets hard, but there are lots of things you could add to improve that.

Hi-score 7300

I was really nonplussed when it started, but I waited patiently until Level 5, as you said. Things really did get interesting. I made it until 12 before being thrown catastrophically into the ocean. Quite a lot of fun here.

The physics aren't bad, and the sparse graphics don't detract. I love the death sound.
Loved the graphics, found that there wasn't much to do, but i'm sure what was done was hard enough to do in 48 hours, nice little game.

description:
Three monkeys compete (local multiplayer) to fill a basket with their favorite coconuts.
Linux and Windows: unzip the distributable and run the "islands" executable (Linux) or the "islands.exe" executable (Windows).
author: easlern
title: Coconuts
comments:
I've chosen to give n/a on fun, it'd be unfair to vote since I can only play alone. Obviously the fun increases with number of players.

I also had some weird hickups, music would repeat for 10 seconds and then things would advance again.
Looks like it has the potential to be quite amusing played with others, but, yeah, requiring 3 players makes it rather hard to play.  Loved the animation and sound though.
Had the same music issues as Endurion.
Too bad about the required multiplayer, this looks like it could have been a lot of fun.

I like the idea, but found that the winner won entirely by chance rather than skill, since the spot where the basket stops and the coconut that spawns above that location are both seemingly random.  Still though, it was fun knocking friends' coconuts out of the trees when the basket wasn't there trying to get as many red coconuts to spawn as possible.

description:
A very short game written entirely from scratch in Standard ML using SDL.
Now available for Windows!  Also, the Mac version is now statically linked against the GMP library, so if you had trouble before, please try it again.
author: wlovas
title: Bouncecrab, Starfish Island
comments:
The link is broken. It should probably point to: http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~wlovas/ludumdare/

I downloaded the OS X version from there, but I got an error trying to run it on an Intel Mac OS X 10.6.3:

Dyld Error Message:
  Library not loaded: /opt/local/lib/libgmp.3.dylib
  Referenced from: /Users/shaktool/Downloads/Bouncecrab.app/Contents/MacOS/explat.exe
  Reason: image not found
Any chance of a Windows version? A lot of people only have Windows :)
I dont have access to any mac's and can therefore not try it out.
Windows version works for me. Game is a bit twitchy, maybe add some more layouts or make the whirlpools mobile?

I like the art style, but wish it were a little more animated. The little dialog boxes are cute, and I like the core idea. Starfish moves a bit too fast, and it's hard to tell when you're being pulled into a whirlpool, but I figured it out. Good job!

The gameplay idea is cool, but the game runs very very quickly, and just holding up + right lets me win every time. Those things together kind of spoil the fun. It's also sad that there's only one level.
Windows link worked for me. The whirlpool-gravity game mechanic is interesting, but it could have been explored much more.
Bad physics, bad graphics and only one level make it a pretty bad game, but if you elaborated it could become okay!

Mac version works fine now. (Mac OS X 10.6.3, MacBook Pro)
If you develop the game further, it could be a really fun game. For example:
- Rotate the whirlpools (Animation)
- Assign a random position for the whirlpools at each level start or create a few maps
- Add a whirlpool for each level (e.g. level 1 has three whirlpools, level 2 four etc.)
- Highscore list
too fast on windows, but could be fun if developed further

The starfish reacts way too fast. It is pure luck that I got to the island. The average play duration is 0.5 seconds :)

Partially randomized stages would increase the replayability a bit.
Really sorry to say I didn't get a lot of fun out of this game. :(

title: Arcipelago
comments:
Try not to have your game files in the root of your archive.
IMO, fullscreen mode should be optional.
Level 6 got a little crazy, managed to jump off over the edge of the water? After that level, the jumping & platforms got to be difficult to navigate. Good game though. :)

Its a good game...
Bad things are, the game can slow down the pc and hard to navigate around some areas in other levels. But its still ok
The game crashed on me after about a minute. What I played looked nice, though.

I WON! =)
Likes: 
- The gong. The gong is awesome. I love that, combined with the roman numeral level numbering system.
- The approach to floating platforms. I particularly like what you did in VI, combining platforming and shooting. Hehehe!
Frustrated by:
- The failed jumps! I swear that many times I hit space to jump, the guy didn't jump. One way you can fix this is to have a timer threshold, so that the player has a few frames *after* they actually fall off the platform where they can jump.

Game Defeated. I won it too. Game play continues to get more complex with play. Game play is solid. level I think 4 or 5 gets a bit confusing with all the extra platforms but I still got it on first shot. I thought being an island is hilarious.

I won, omg!
So, the good - Graphics where simple, but worked pretty well. Controls where relativity intuitive, The title screen looked nice, level pacing and difficulty increase was dead on.
the bad -  Totally by the books game-play. You score an n/a in innovation. I also didnt realize the clouds where moving at first due to scrolling everything but the water. It looked like I just arbitrarily started floating. Didnt help matters that the clouds moved or didnt move totally dependent on the level, so I had no way of predicting what was going on.
the ugly - well, nothing was outright ugly. Im a little unclear on what the player was. Was he an island? Did this game even use the island theme? Those floating blocks could have been pretty much anything... (I mean, they did LOOK like islands, but then they sank for some reason, and where mostly floating in the sky...)

Worked fine for me, some tricky parts there.
I also had the failed jump problem. Quite a few times I died because the jump didn't seem to work.
A strange take on the theme. A dude made out of islands? The level design is a bit haphazard, but had some neat ideas, like riding the platforms.

Neat concept. Simple. It got a bit difficult after the first few levels (because of how hard it is to tell where the finish is) and I think the controls could be slightly improved to be more responsive. The sound effects were good too, even though there were only two I experienced.

Also *highfive* on having a number at the beginning of your username. :D

X8H WIN!

Feel free to put your game files wherever you want. :) But it did make me pretty dizzy to play fullscreen. It probably would have helped if the scroll wasn't completely locked to my player.

This was a modest platformer that I played through to the end and had a good time with. The graphics of the main character are real weird but pretty funny. The puzzles weren't too frustrating because restarting them was fast (sometimes too abrupt, and I didn't even see what happened), but I also usually failed because it didn't register my jump because I hadn't landed before hitting space, or something. A little leeway for the player here would have been nice to reduce cruelty. Some of the platforms in some of the levels seemed unmotivated, so that was kinda a downside. Still, enjoyable. :)
Weird physics and main character, but not too bad.

eli's comment is... WIN.

This game is... STRANGE.

But that is... GOOD.

description:
Instructions: Help your crustacean to clean the island. Find all cans in the island and Avoid mice. Move your hero using the mouse pointer.
You don't need to press any button in this game... actually you need to press any mouse button to start, but... you know.
The game runs at fullscreen 1024x768x32.
Clean the Island!! was created for Ludum Dare 17 competition (Theme: Islands, April 23rd-25th 2010).
It was made using PlayBasic for coding, Audacity and Acoustica Mixcraft for sound and music, and Paint.net for "graphics".
Note: Only one level, sorry I run out of time :(
author: jfroco
title: Clean the Island!!
comments: Nice game jfroco, sweet music and easy to understand.

I actually really liked this game, very simple, but challenging and fun.
I wish the ending would be a bit more rewarding, it seems that touching the can yielded similar results to touching one of the mice... (Apart from the sound effect)
Nice music as well.


Good job man.
Simple yet fun. I really liked the graphics and the music. Would of liked to see more levels but we do what we can right? great job.
Nice game, lovely music. A shame there are not more levels.

Rad music. And yes, needs more levels. It will be interesting to see if you can find the line between challenging and frustrating with this type of gameplay.

Congrats!

The music is great.  These have to be the biggest pixels I've ever seen.  I liked the graphics... it all felt very snappy and happening, like if I got the can I'd be kicked back to the Wario Ware menu for my next game.

I'd like to point out that mice have ears, though.

Good effort, very nice and clear graphics. I felt the theme was kind of tacked on. Great music! I liked the logistic complications of being surrounded by mice. There are probably interesting levels to be made.

description:
The Monster of Canvey Island has returned after fifty five years!
Try to cause as much havok before she sadly suffocates due to lack of water.
Move her with the arrow keys, you can also smash cars in the foreground with the space bar.
The game was made in Game Maker v.8
Sadly I did run short of time, there were a lot of features which I cut at the last minute as they weren't entirely finished, such as people on fire (only thing that could hurt the create) knocking down buildings, as well as a variety of people, random sfx for the creature, a better background, plus much much more :)
Overall though I'm quite happy with the finished product even though it is simple :)
Also for those that don't read the story the creature was found in Canvey Island which is in Essex, UK.
I hope you enjoy playing it!
author: Catmoo
title: Attack of the Canvey Island Monster
comments:
Love the look of the creature! Very cool and unusual. Gorgeous gfx on the title screen (I hope those photographic elements were taken during the compo weekend, tho. I'll overlook the newspaper clipping but the rest should be original) ...

I wish the buildings, cars and clouds had more personality, like the monster and the titles, but they're still nice and clean and look good.

Not too much gameplay -- nothing (not even time?) seemed to hurt the monster, so there wasn't much challenge to it. With a little more work, this could be an awesome rampage-style basher game.

Also.. "Noooooo!"... great stuff!

Good Stuff!  I really liked the art and sound effects.  Reminds me a lot of the Rampage series.   

Gameplay got a little repetitive after a bit.

kay....
The Good - Graphics where mostly good. The title screen and explanation was awesome, felt like a b-movie, and Im always for pretty girls looking terrified of giant monsters. The monster... was well drawn. Ill get into the monster more later. Also, you have a good moniker, so that's cool.
The Bad - Gameplay was nonexistent. Straight up. There was no game here, I moved left, sometimes I hit spacebar to crush a car. I couldnt even climb and destroy buildings, or eat people. I was really hoping for a rampage knockoff, and instead just hit left for awhile.
The Ugly - First off, the monster was just a penis with legs and gills. I dont know about you, but Im not that scared of a wang. I mean, I guess the size was a little bit intimidating. My cock is nowhere near the size of a skyscraper, so I guess I should have feared being emasculated? The sound... might fall under good and might fall under ugly. I flip flopped on it. I liked that you actually bothered recording audio for it, and it sounded thoroughly cheesy. Thats a good thing, helped the feel. That being said, it got old, fast. It was also sampled fairly poorly and ofsuch had a bit of feedback on it that kind of hurt my head. I probably wouldnt have noticed that last part if I wasnt an audio engineer though, so Im giving you 3 in sound.

Oh, dear... I love the use of theme for this, and that fish with legs freaks the heck out of me. I think this would be really interesting as a "where in the world is the canvey island monster?" type game! Crazy =)
Very clever and funny theme!  Wish there was more game to it, but it was entertaining for a while, at least. =)

The art on the main creature (especially) and the intro material is great, and I thought the theme was weird and cute. There's not much to do other than walk and smash stuff, so it sort of plays as an animated comic, and it's a bit too long for that. But I guess that's kind of like a metaphor for being a fish with feet. :)
Loved the sound and art. Liked how it tied to a real "monster." Wish there was some more gameplay.

Awww, dang. I hoped I could also smash the buildings, but it wasn't meant to be :(
Awesome base, but sadly not more than that.
Seemed a bit limited and was reaching in terms of the theme but was funny non the less.

I laughed when I read zez's comments because I was thinking the same thing - the monster is very phallic. Also there is no gameplay - I never lost any energy, and all I did was hold the right arrow and space bar at the same time. After a minute and a half or so the sound was destroying me ears and that was that. I love the concept, but that's about it.

Shame you couldnt put everything in it that you wanted, the graphics are real neat, and make up for the lack of gameplay, perhaps if you had the monster's health depleting over time there would have been more of a sense of danger. Very interesting use of the theme, the audio is awesome, love that scream on the main menu.
